note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Flouriſh. Enter Aſtorax King of Paphos, his Siſter Calis, traine, and Cleanthe, Lucippe Gentlewomen at one doore; At the other Eumenes a Souldier.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: _HEalth to my Soveraigne.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Eumenes, welcome:
Welcome to Paphos ſouldier to our love,
And that faire health ye wiſh us through the Campe
May it diſperſe it ſelfe, and make all happy;
How does the Generall, the valiant Memnon,
And how his wars, Eumenes?

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: The Gods have giv'n you (royall Sir) a Souldier
Better ne're ſought a danger, more approv'd
In way of war, more maſter of his fortunes,
Expert in leading 'em; in doing valiant,
In following all his deeds to Victories,
And holding fortune certaine there.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O Souldier,
Thou ſpeak'ſt a man indeed; a Generall Generall,
A ſoule conceiv'd a Souldier.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Ten ſet Battells
Againſt the ſtrong uſurper Diocles
Whom long experience had begot a Leader
Ambition rais'd too mighty: hath your Memnon
Won, and won gloriouſly, diſtreſt and ſhooke him
Even from the head of all his hopes to nothing:
In three he beat the thunder-bolt his brother
Forc'd him to wall himſelfe up: there not ſafe,
Shooke him with warlike Engines like an earthquake,
Till like a ſnaile he left his ſhell and crawl'd
By night, and hidious darkneſſe to deſtruction:
Diſarm'd for ever riſing more; twelve Caſtles,
Some though impregnable; Townes twice as many
Countries that like the wind knew no command
But ſavage wildneſſe; hath this Generall
With loſſe of blood & youth, through ſtorms & tempeſts
Cal'd to your faire obedience. Drum within.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O my Souldier
That thou wert now within my arms; what drums- Drum
Are thoſe that beat Eumenes?

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: His my Soveraigne;
Himſelfe i'th head of conqueſt drawing home,
An old man now to offer up his glories,
And endleſſe conqueſt at your ſhrine,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Goe all,
And entertaine him with all Ceremonie,
Wee'le keep him now a Courtier.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Sir, a ſtrange one,
Pray God his language beare it; by my life, Sir
He knowes no complement, nor curious caſting
Of words into fit places ere he ſpeak 'em,
He can ſay fight well fellow, and i'le thanke thee:
He that muſt eat, muſt ſweat; bring up the reare there,
Or charge that wing of horſe home. Floriſh.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Goe too, goe too. Ent. Memnon and a traine of Courtiers & ſouldiers, two Captains, Chilax.
Valiant and wiſe are twins Sir: welcome, welcome,
Welcome my fortunate and famous Generall,
High in thy Princes favour as in fame,
Welcome to Peace and Paphos.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Thanke your Grace,
And would to God my dull tongue had that ſweetneſſe
To thanke you as I ſhould; but pardon me,
My ſword and I ſpeake roughly Sir: your battells
I dare well ſay, I have fought well; for I bring ye
That lazie end you wiſh for Peace, ſo fully,
That no more name of war is: who now thinkes
Sooner or ſafer theſe might have bin ended.
Begin 'em If ye dare againe; I'le thanke him.
Souldier and Souldiers Mate theſe twenty five yeares,
At length your Generall, (as one whoſe merit
Durſt looke upon no leſſe,) I have waded through
Dangers would damp't theſe ſoft ſoules, but to heare of
The maidenheads of thouſand lives hangs here Sir,
Since which time, Prince, I know no Court but Marſhall,
No oylie language, but the ſhock of Armes,
No dalliance but with death; No lofty meaſures
But weary and ſad marches, cold and hunger,
Larums at midnight, Valours ſelfe would ſhake at,
Yet I ne're ſhrunke. Balls of conſuming Wildfire,
That lickt men up like lightning, have I laught at,
And toſt 'em back againe like childrens trifles
Upon the edges of my Enemies ſwords
I have marcht like whirle-windes, fury at this hand waiting,
Death at my right; Fortune my forlorne hope,
When I have grapled with deſtruction,
And tug'd with pale fac'd Ruine, Night and Miſchiefe,
Frighted to ſee a new day breake in bloud,
And every where I conquer'd; and for you ſir,
Mothers have wanted wombes to make me famous,
And blowne ambition dangers; Thoſe that griev'd ye,
I have taken order for i'th' earth: thoſe fooles
That ſhall hereafter.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: No more wars my ſouldier: K. takes Mem. aſide and talkes with him.
We muſt now treat of peace ſir.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: How he talkes,
How gloriouſly.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: A goodly timber'd fellow,
Valiant no doubt.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: If valour dwell in vaunting;
In what a phraſe he ſpeakes as if his actions
Could be ſet of in nothing but a noiſe,
Sure has a drum in's mouth.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I wonder wenches
How he would ſpeake to us.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Nothing but larum
Tell us whoſe throat he cut, ſhew us his ſword,
And bleſſe it for ſure biting.

sp.speaker: Lucippe.
sp.l: And t like your Grace,
I doe not thinke he knowes us what we are,
Or to what end; for I have heard his followers
Affirme he never ſaw a woman that exceeded
A Sutlers wife yet, or in execution
Old bedrid Beldames without teeth or tongues,
That would not flie his furie? how he lookes.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: This way devoutly.

sp.speaker: Cal
sp.l: Sure his Lordſhip's viewing
Our Fortifications.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: If he mount at me,
I may chance choake his Battery.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Still his eye
Keeps quarter this way: Ʋenus grant his valour
Be not in love.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: If he be, preſently
Expect a Herrald and a Trompet with ye
To bid ye render; we two Perdu's pay for't elſe.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I'le leave ye to my ſiſter, and theſe Ladies
To make your welcome fuller: my good ſouldier
We muſt now turne your ſternneſſe into Courtſhip
When ye have done there; to your fair repoſe ſir: Floriſh.
I know you need it Memnon, welcome gentlemen. Ex. Ki.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: Now he begins to march: Madam the Van's yours,
Keep your ground ſure; 'tis for your ſpurrs.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: O Venus. He kneeles amaz'd and forgets to ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: How he ſtares on me.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Knight him Madam, knight him
He will grow tooth' ground els.

sp.speaker: Eumenes.
sp.l: Speake ſir, 'tis the Princeſſe.

sp.speaker: 1 Capt.
sp.l: Ye ſhame your ſelfe, ſpeake to her

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Riſe and ſpeake ſir.
Ye are welcome to the Court, to me, to all ſir,

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Is he not deafe?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: The Gentleman's not well.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Fie noble Generall,

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Give him freſh aire his colour goes, how do ye?
The Princeſſe will be glad ſir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Peace, and heare me.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Command a ſilence there.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I love thee Lady.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I thank your Lordſhip heartily: proceed ſir.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Lord how it ſtuck in's ſtomack like a ſurfet.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: It breaks apace now from him, God be thanked,
What a fine ſpoken man he is.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: A choice one of ſingular variety in carriage.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Yes and I warrant you he knows his diſtance.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: With all my heart I love thee.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: A hearty gentleman,
And I were eene an arrand beaſt, my Lord,
But I lov'd you againe.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Good Lady kiſſe me.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: I marry, Mars, there thou cam'ſt cloſe up to her.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Kiſs you at firſt my Lord, 'tis no faire faſhion,
Our lips are like Roſe buds, blowne with mens breaths,
They looſe both ſap and ſavour; there's my hand ſir.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Fie, fie, my Lord, this is too rude.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Unhand me,
Conſume me if I hurt her; good ſweet Lady
Let me but looke upon thee.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Doe.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Yet.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Well ſir.
Take your full view.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Bleſſe your eyes ſir.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Mercie,
Is this the man they talkt of for a ſouldier,
So abſolute and Excellent: O the Gods,
If I were given to that vanitie
Of making ſport with men for ignorance,
What a moſt precious ſubject had I purchas'd?
Speake for him gentlemen: ſome one that knowes,
What the man ailes; and can ſpeake ſenſe.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Sure Madam,
This fellow has been a rare Hare finder
See how his eyes are ſet.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Some one goe with me,
I'le ſend him ſomething, for his head, poore gentleman,
Is troubled with the ſtaggers.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Keep him darke,
He will run March mad elſe, the fumes of Battell's
Aſcend into his braines,

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Clap to his feet
An old Drum head, to draw the thunder downward.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Look to him gentlemen: farwell, Lord I am ſorry
We cannot kiſſe at this time, but believe it
Wee'le find an houre for all: God keep my children,
From being ſuch ſweet Souldiers; Softly wenches,
Leſt we diſturbe his dreame. Exit Calis & Ladies.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Why this is Monſtrous.

sp.speaker: 1 Capt.
sp.l: A ſtrange forgetfulneſſe, yet ſtill he holds it.

sp.speaker: 2 Capt.
sp.l: Though he ne're ſaw a woman of great faſhion
Before this day, yet my thinks 'tis poſſible
He might imagine what they are, and what
Belongs unto 'em; meere ●eport of others.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Piſh, his head had other whimſies in't: my Lord,
Death I think y'are ſtrook dumb; my good Lord Generall

sp.speaker: 1 Capt.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: That I doe love ye Madam; and ſo love ye
An't like your grace.

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.l: He has bin ſtudying this ſpeech.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Who doe ye ſpeake to ſir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Why where's the Lady
The woman, the faire woman.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.l: Who?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: The Princeſſe,
Give me the Princeſſe.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Give yee counſell rather
To uſe her like a Princeſſe: Fy my Lord,
How have you borne your ſelfe, how nakedly
Laid your ſoule open: and your ignorance
To be a ſport to all; report and honour;
Drew her to doe you favours, and you bluntly,
Without conſideration what, or how ſhe was
Neither collecting reaſon, nor diſtinction.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Why, what did I my maſters?

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: All that ſhewes
A man unhandſome, undigeſted done.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Did not I kneele unto her?

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Dumbe and ſenſleſſe,
As though ye had bin cut out for your fathers tombe,
Or ſtuck a land-marke; when ſhe ſpoke unto you,
Being the excellence of all our Iſland,
Ye ſtar'd upon her, as ye had ſeene a monſter

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Was I ſo fooliſh; I confeſſe Eumenes,
I never ſaw before ſo brave an outſide
But did I kneele ſo long

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Till they laught at ye,
And when you ſpoke, I am aſham'd to tell ye
What 'twas my Lord; how farre from order;
Bleſſe me, is't poſſible the wild noiſe of a warre
And what ſhe only teaches ſhould poſſeſſe ye,
Knowledge to treat with her, and full diſcretion
Being at flood ſtill in ye, and in peace,
And manly converſation ſmooth and civill,
Where gracefulneſſe and glory twyn together
Thruſt your ſelfe out an exile?
Doe you know ſir, what ſtate ſhe carries?
What great obedience waits at her backe continually?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: She ne're commanded
A hundred thouſand men, as I have done,
Nor ne're won battell; Say I would have kiſt her.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: There was a dainty offer too, a rare one.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Why, ſhe is a woman, is ſhe not?

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: She is ſo.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Why, very well; what was ſhe made for then?
Is ſhe not young and handſome bred to breed?
Doe not men kiſſe faire women? if they doe,
If lips be not unlawfull ware; Why a Princeſſe
Is got the ſame way that we get a begger,
Or I am coſen'd; and the ſelfe-ſame way
Shee muſt be handled e're ſhe get another,
That's rudeneſſe is it not?

sp.speaker: 2. Cap.
sp.l: To her 'tis held ſo, & rudnes in that high degree.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: 'Tis reaſon,
But I will be more punctuall; pray what thought ſhe?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Her thoughts were mercifull, but ſhe laught at ye,
Pittying the pooreneſſe of your complement,
And ſo ſhe left ye, good ſir ſhape your ſelfe
To underſtand the place, and noble perſons
You live with now.

sp.speaker: 1. Cap.
sp.l: Let not thoſe great deſerts
The King hath layd up of ye, and the people,
Be blaſted with ill bearing.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: The whole name of ſouldier, then will ſuffer,

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Shee's a ſweet one.
And good ſirs leave your exhortations
They come untimely to me, I have braines
That beate above your reaches: Shee's a Princeſſe,
That's all: I have killed a King, that's greater.
Come let's to dinner, if the Wine be good,
You ſhall perceive ſtrange wiſdome in my blood.

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: Well, would thou wert i'the wars again
Old Memnon, there thou wouldſt talke toth' purpoſe,
And the proudeſt of all theſe Court Camelions
Would be glad to find it ſenſe too: plague of this
Dead peace, this baſtard breeding lowzie lazie idleneſſe,
Now we muſt learne to pipe, and pick our livings
Out of old rotten ends: theſe twenty five yeares
I have ſerv'd my Countrie, loſt my youth and bloud,
Expos'd my life to dangers more then dayes.
Yet let me tell my wants, I know their anſwers,
The King is bound to right me, they good people
Have but from hand to mouth, looke to your wives
Your yong trim wives, your high-day wives, your march-paines,
For if the ſouldiers find not recompence,
As yet there's none a hatching; I beleeve
You men of wars, the men of wars will nick ye,
For ſterve nor beg they muſt not, my ſmall meanes
Are gone in fumo: here to raiſe a better
Unleſſe it be with lying, or dog flattering,
At which our Nations excellent; obſerving dog-dayes,
When this good Lady broyles, and would be baſted
By that good Lord or ſuch like morall learnings,
Is here impoſſible; Well, I will rub among 'em
If any thing for honeſtie be gotten,
Thou't be but bread and cheeſe I can be ſatisfied,
If otherwiſe the wind blow, ſtiffe as I am
Yet I ſhall learne to ſhuffle: There's an old Laſſe
That ſhall be nameleſſe yet alive, my laſt hope,
Has often got me my pocket full of crownes
If all faile, Jack-Dawes, are you alive ſtill?
Then I ſee the coaſt cleare, when fooles and boyes can proſper.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.l: Brave Lievtenant

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Haile to the man of worſhip.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: You are fine ſirs,
Moſt paſſing fine at all points.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.l: As ye ſee ſir,
Home-bred and handſome, we cut not out our clothes ſir
At halfe ſword as your Taylors doe, and pinck 'em
With Pikes and Partizans, we live retir'd ſir
Gentlemen like, and jealous of our honours.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Very fine Foole, and fine Boy, Peace playes with you
As the wind playes with feathers, dances ye
You grind with all guſts gallants.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: We can bounce ſir,
When you Soldados bend i'th' hams, and frisk too.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.l: When twenty of your trip-coats turn their tip|pets,
And your cold ſallets without ſalt or vineger
By wambling in your ſtomacks, hemp and hobnailes
Will beare no price now, hanging and old harneis
Are like to over-run us.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Whores and hot houſes.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Surgeons and Sirenges ring out your ſance-bells.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Your Jubile, your Jubile.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: How our St. Georges will beſtride the Dragons
The red and ramping Dragons.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Advanc't foole.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: But then the ſting i'th' taile boy.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: For ſo much the more danger, the more honour.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: You'r very pleaſant with our occupation Gent.
Which very like amongſt theſe fierie Serpents
May light upon a Blind-worme of your blood,
A Mother or a Siſter.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Mine's paſt ſaddle
You ſhould be ſure of her elſe: but ſay Sir Huon
Now the Drums doubbes, & the ſticks turn'd bed-ſtaves,
All the old Foxes hunted to their holes,
The Iron age return'd to Eribus,
And Honorificabilitudinitatibus
Thruſt out o'th' Kingdome by the head and ſhoulders,
What trade doe you meane to follow.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: That's a queſtion.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Yes and a learned queſtion if ye marke it,
Conſider and ſay on.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Fooling as thou doſt, that's the beſt trade I take it.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Take it ſtrait then
For feare your fellowes be before ye, harke ye Lievtenant
Foolings the thing, the thing worth all your fightings,
When all's done ye muſt foole ſir.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Well, I muſt then.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: But doe you know what fooling is; true fooling
The circumſtances that belong unto it,
For every idle knave that ſhowes his teeth
Wants and would live can Juggle tumble, fiddle,
Make a dog face, or can abuſe his fellow,
Is not a foole at firſt daſh, you ſhall find ſir
Strange turnings in this trade; to foole is nothing
As fooling has bin but to foole the faire way,
The new way, as the beſt men foole their friends,
For all men get by fooling meerely fooling,
Deſert does nothing valiant, wiſe, vertuous,
Are things that walke by without bread or breeches,

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I partly credit that.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Fine wits, fine wits ſir,
There's the young Boy, he does well in his way too,
He could not live elſe in his Maſters abſence;
He tyes a Ladyes garters ſo, ſo, pretily,
Say his hand ſlip, but ſay ſo.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Why let it ſlip then.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: 'Tis ten to one the body ſhall come after,
And he that workes deſerves his wages.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: That's true.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Hee riddles finely to a waiting Gentlewoman
Expounds dreames like a Prophet, dreames himſelfe too,
And wiſhes all dreames true; they cry Amen,
And there's a Memorandum: he can ſing too
Bawdy enough to pleaſe old Ladies: he lies rarely,
Pawnes ye a ſute of clothes at all points, fully,
Can pick a pocket if ye pleaſe, or casket;
Liſps when he liſts to catch a Chambermaid,
And calls his Hoſteſſe mother, theſe are things now,
If a man meane to live, to fight and ſwagger,
Beaten about the Eares with bawling ſheepskins,
Cut to the ſoule for Summer: here an arme loſt,
And there a leg; his honourable head
Seal'd up in ſalves and ſearclothes, like a packet,
And ſo ſent over to an Hoſpitall, ſtand there, charge there,
Sweare there, whore there, dead there,
And all this ſport for cheeſe, and chines of dog-fleſh,
And money when two Wedneſdayes meet together,
Where to be lowzie is a Gentleman,
And he that weares a cleane ſhirt has his
Shrowd on.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I'le be your ſcholler, come if I like fooling.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: You cannot chooſe but like it, fight you one day
I'le foole another, when your Surgeons paid,
And all your leakes ſtopt, ſee whoſe ſlops are heavieſt,
I'le have a ſhilling for a can of wine,
When you ſhall have two Sergeants for a counter.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Come learn of us Lievtenant, hang your Iron up,
Wee'le find you cooler warrs.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Come let's together,
I'le ſee your tricks, and as I like 'em. — Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Why was there not ſuch women in the camp then
Prepar'd to make me know 'em.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: 'Twas no place ſir.

sp.speaker: 1. Capt.
sp.l: Why ſhould they live in Tumults: they are crea|tures
Soft and of ſober natures.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Cou'd not your wives,
Your mothers, or your ſiſters have been ſent for
To exerciſe upon.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: We thanke your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: 2. Cap.
sp.l: But doe you meane?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I doe meane.

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.l: What ſir?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: To ſee her,
And ſee thee hang'd too, and thou anger'ſt me,
And thouſands of your throats cut, get ye from me
Ye keepe a prating of your points of manners,
And fill my head with lowzie circumſtances,
Better have Ballets in 't your courtly worſhips,
How to put off my hat, you how to turne me,
And you forſooth to blow my noſe diſcreetly;
Let me alone, for I will love her, ſee her,
Talke to her, and mine owne way.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: Shee's the Princeſſe.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Why let her be the devill, I have ſpoke,
When Thunder durſt not check me, I muſt love,
I know ſhe was a thing kept for me.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: And I know ſir,
Though ſhe were born yours, yet your ſtrange behaviour
And want.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Thou lieſt.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: I doe not.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: I doe not lye ſir,
I ſay you want faire language, nay 'tis certaine
You cannot ſay good morrow.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Ye Dog-whelpes,
The proudeſt of your prating tongues.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: Doe kill us,
Kill us for telling truth, for my part Generall
I would not live to ſee men make a may-game
Of him I have made a Maſter, kill us quickly,
Then ye may.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: Doe what you liſt, draw your ſword childiſhly
Upon your ſervants that are bound to tell ye
I am weary of my life.

sp.speaker: 1 Capt.
sp.l: And I.

sp.speaker: 2 Capt.
sp.l: And all ſir.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: Goe to the Princeſſe make her ſport, cry to her
I am the glorious man of warre.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Pray ye leave me,
I am ſorry I was angry, I'le thinke better,
Pray no more words.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: Good ſir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Nay then.

sp.speaker: 2 Capt.
sp.p: We are gone ſir. Exeunt Eume. & Captains.

sp.speaker: Caliſ.
sp.l: How came he hither, ſee for heavens ſake wenches,
What faces, and what poſtures he puts on, Mem. walks aſide full of ſtrange geſtures.
I doe not thinke he is perfect.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: If your love
Have not betrayd his little wits, he's well enough.
As well as he will be.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Marke how he Muſes.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Has a Battalia now in's braines, he draws out now
Have at ye Harpers.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: See, ſee, there the fire failes.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Look what an Alphabet of faces he runs through,

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: O love, loue, how amorouſly thou look'ſt
In an old ruſty armour.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I'le away, for by my troth I feare him.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Feare the gods Madam,
And never care what man can doe, this fellow
Withall his frights about him and his furies,
His larums and his Launces, Swords and Targets,
Nay caſe him up in armour Cap-a-pe,
Yet durſt I undertake within two houres,
If he durſt charge to give him ſuch a ſhake
Should ſhake his valour off, and make his ſhankes too

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: For ſhame no more.

sp.speaker: Caliſ.
sp.l: Hee muſes ſtill.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: The Devill.
Why ſhould this old dried timber chopt with thunder.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Old wood burnes quickeſt.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Out you would ſay Madam,
Give me a green ſtick that may hold me heat
And ſmoke me ſoundly too: a turnes, and ſees ye.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: There's no avoiding now, have at ye. Memnon comes to her.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Lady,
The more I looke upon ye. Stays her.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: The more you may ſir.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Let him alone.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I would deſire your patience
The more I ſay I looke, the more Stays her.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: My Fortune
'Tis very apt Sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Women let my fortune
And me alone I wiſh ye, pray come this way
And ſtand you ſtill there Ladie

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Leave the words Sir, and leap into the meaning

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Then againe.
I tell you I doe love ye

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Why

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: No queſtions: pray no more queſtions.
I doe love you. Infinitely, why doe you ſmile.
Am I ridiculous

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I am monſtrous fearefull, no I joye you love me

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Joye on then and be proud on't, I doe love ye,
Stand ſtill doe not trouble me you Women.
He loves you Ladie at whoſe feete has kneeld
Princes to beg their freedomes, he whoſe valour
Has over run whole Kingdomes

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: That makes me doubt Sir
'Twill over run me to

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: He whoſe Sword

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Talke not ſo big Sir, you will fright the Princeſſe.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Ha. Lucip. No forſooth

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I know ye have done wonders.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I have and will doe more and greater braver.
And for your beautie miracles, name that kingdome
And talke your choice:

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Sir I am not ambitious

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Ye ſhalbe, 'tis the child of glory: ſhe that I love
Whom my deſires ſhall magnifie time ſtories
And all the Empire of the Earth:

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I would faine aske him.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Prethee be quiet, he will beate us both els.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: What will ye make me then Sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I will make thee
Stand ſtill and hold thy peace, I have a heart Ladie

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Ye were a monſter els

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: A loving heart
A truly loving heart:

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Alas how came it

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I would you had it in your hand ſweet Ladie
To ſee the truth it beares ye:

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Doe you give it.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: That was well thought upon:

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: 'Twill put him too't wench;

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: And you ſhall ſee I dare accept it Sir
Tak't in my hand and view it: if I finde it
A loving and a ſweet heart as you call it
I am bound, I am

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: No more Ile ſend it to ye
As I have honour in me you ſhall have it

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Hanſomlye done Sir, and perfum'd by all meanes
The weathers warme Sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: With all circumſtance

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: A napkin wrought moſt curiouſlie;

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Divinely

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Put in a goblet of pure gold

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Yes in Iacynth
That ſhe may ſee the ſpirits through

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Ye have greas'd him
For chewing love again in haſt

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: If he ſhould doe it

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: If Heaven ſhould fall we ſhould have larkes, he doe

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: See how he thinkes upon't

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: He will thinke theſe three yeares
Ere he prove ſuch an aſſe, I lik't his offer
There was no other way to put him of els.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I will doe it
Ladie expect my heart

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I doe Sir:

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Love it and ſo I leave ye. Ex. Mem.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Either he is ſtarke mad
Or els I thinke he meanes it

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: He muſt be ſtarke mad
Or he will never doe it, 'tis vaine glory
And want of judgement that provokes this in him
Sleepe and ſocietie cures all his heart
No no good Gentleman ther's more belongs too't
Hearts are at higher prizes, lets goe in
And there examine him a little better.
Shut all the doores behind for feare he follow
I hope I have loſt a lover, and am glad on't. Exit. Lady.

div.head: Scaena Prima.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: 'Tis but to die, dogs doe it, ducks with d●bling,
Birds ſing away their ſoules, and babyes ſleep 'em,
Why doe I talke of that is treble vantage,
For in the other world ſhe is bound to have me,
Her Princely word is paſt: my great deſert too
Will draw her to come after preſently
'Tis juſtice, and the gods muſt ſee it done too
Beſides no Brother, Father, kindred there
Can hinder us, all languages are a like ●oo
There love is everlaſting, ever young
Free from diſeaſes, ages, jealouſies.
Bawdes, beldames, painters, purgers, die, 'tis nothing
Men drowne themſelves for joye to draw in Juleps
When they are hot with wine, In dreames we doe it,
And many a handſome wench that loves the ſport well
Gives up her ſoule ſo in her lovers boſome,
But I muſt be inciſde firſt, cut and open'd
My heart and handſomelie taine from me, ſtaie there
Dead once ſtay, let me thinke agen, who doe I know there
For els to wander up and downe unwaited on
And unregarded in my place and project
Is for a ſowters ſoule, not an old Souldiers.
My brave old Regiments: I there it goes
That have bin killd before me, right,

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: Is here, and I muſt trouble him.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Then thoſe I have conquer'd
To make my traine full:

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: My Captaines then:

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Sir I beſeech ye

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: For to meete her there
Being a Princeſſe and a Kings ſole Siſter
With great accommodation muſt be cared for

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Weigh but the Souldiers povertie

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Mine owne troope firſt
For they ſhall die:

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: How whats this

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Next:

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Shall I ſpeake lowder Sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: A ſquare Battalia:

sp.speaker: hi.
sp.l: You doe not thinke of us.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Their Armours guilded:

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Good noble Sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: And round about ſuch Engines
Shall make hell ſhake:

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Ye doe not mock me

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: For Sir
I will be ſtrange as brave

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Ye may conſider
You know we have ſerv'd you long enough

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: No Souldier
That ever landed on the bleſt Elizium
Did or ſhall march, as I will

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Would ye would march Sir
Up to the King and get us

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: King nor Keiſer
Shall equall me in that world

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: What a devill ayles he

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Next the rare beauties of thoſe townes I fir'd

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I ſpeake of mony Sir:

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Ten thouſand Coaches

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: O pounds Sir, pounds I beſeech your Lordſhip
Let Coaches run out of your remembrance

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: In which the wanton Cupids; and the graces
Drawne with the Weſterne winds kindling deſires,
And then our Poets.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Then our pay

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: For Chilax when the triumph comes; the Princeſſe
Then for I will have a Heaven made

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Bleſſe your Lordſhip I
Stand ſtill Sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: So I doe and in it

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Death Sir
You talke you know not what

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Such rare deviſes:
Make me I ſay a Heaven

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I ſay ſo too Sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: For here ſhall run a Conſtellation

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: And there a piſſing Conduit

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: With wine Sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: A Sun there in his hight, there ſuch a planet

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: But wher's our mony where runs that

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Money
Money ant like your Lordſhip

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Why all the carriage, ſhall come behind the ſtuff
Rich hangings, treaſure
Or ſay we have none

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I may ſay ſo truly
For hang me if I have a groat: I have ſerv'd well
And like an honeſt man: I ſee no reaſon

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Thou muſt needs die good Chilax

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Very well Sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I will have honeſt, valiant ſoules about me
I cannot miſſe thee

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Dye?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Yes die, and Pelius
Eumenes and Polibius: I ſhall thinke
Of more within theſe two howres

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Die Sir?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I Sir
And ye ſhall die

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: When I beſeech your Lordſhip

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: To morrow ſee ye doe die

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: A ſhort warning,
Troth Sir I am ill prepar'd

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I die my ſelfe then
Beſide ther's reaſon

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I pray thee tell me
For thou art a great dreamer

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I can dreame Sir
If I eate well and ſleep well

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Was it never
By dreame or apparition open'd to thee?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Hees mad

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: What the other world was, or Elizium?
Didſt never travell in thy ſleepe?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: To Tauernes
When I was drunke ore night: or to a wench
Ther's an Elizium for yee, a young Ladie
Wrapt round about ye like a ſnake: is that it?
Or if that ſtrange Elizium that you talke of
Be where the Devill is, I have dream't of him
And that I have had him by the hornes, and rid him
He trotts the Dagger out 'oth ſheath

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: The bleſſed fields, man

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I know no fields bleſſed, but thoſe I have gain'd by
I have dreamp't I have bin in Heaven too

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: There, handle that place; that's Elizium

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Brave ſinging, and brave dancing
And rare things

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: All full of flowers

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: And Pot hearbes

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Bowers for lovers
And everlaſting ages of delight

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I ſlept not ſo far

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Meet me on thoſe bancks
Some two dayes hence

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: In dreame Sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: No in death Sir
And there I muſter all, and pay the Souldier
Away, no more, no more

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: God keepe your Lordſhip
This is fine dancing for us

sp.speaker: Siphax.
sp.l: Wher's the Generall

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Ther's the old ſigne of Memnon, where the ſoule is
You may goe looke as I have

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: What's the matter

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Why queſtion him and ſee; he talkes of Devills
Hells, Heavens, Princes, powers, and Potentates,
You muſt to'th pot too

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.p: Do you know Elizium a tale he talkes the wild gooſe chaſe of

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Elizium? I have red of ſuch a place.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Then get he to him
Ye are as fine company as can be fitted. Exit Chilax.
Your worſhips fairelie mett

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Mercy upon us,
What ailes this Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Proviſion

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: How his head workes.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Betweene two ribbes
If he cut ſhort or mangle me; Ile take him
And twirle his neck about

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Now Gods defend us

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: In a pure cup tranſparant with a writing
To ſignifie

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: I never knew him thus
Sure is bewitcht, or poyſond;

sp.speaker: Mem,
sp.l: Whoſe there

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: I Sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Come hither Siphax

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Yes; how does your Lordſhip

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Well God a mercy Souldier, very well
But prithee tell me

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Any thing I can Sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: What durſt thou doe to gaine the rareſt beautie
The VVorld has

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: That the world has? 'tis worth doing

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Is it ſo? but what doing beares it?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Why any thing, all dangers it appeares to

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Name ſome of thoſe things; doe

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: I would undertake Sir
A voyage round about the VVorld

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Short Siphax,
A merchant does it to ſpice potts of ale

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: I woo'd ſwim in armour

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Short ſtill: a poore Jade
Loden will take a ſtreame and ſtem it ſtrongly
To leap a Mare

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: The plague I durſt

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Still ſhorter
Ile cure it with an Onyon

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Surfetts

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Short ſtill
They are often Phyſicks for our healths and help us.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: I woo'd ſtand a breach

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Thine honour bids thee Souldier
'Tis ſhame to find a ſecond cauſe

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: I durſt Sir
Fight with the felleſt Monſter

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: That s the pooreſt,
Man was ordained their Maſter; durſt ye die Sir?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: How? die my Lord!

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Die Siphax: take thy ſword
And come by that doore to her; ther's a prize
To buy a luſtie love at

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: I am well content Sir
To proove no purchaſer

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Away thou world worme,
Thou win a matchles beautie?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: 'Tis to looſ't Sir
For being dead wher's the reward I reach at,
The love I labour for?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: There it begins foole
Thou art meerly cozend; for the loves wee now know
Are but the heats of half an houre; and hated
Deſires ſtir'd up by nature to increaſe her
Licking of one another to a luſt;
Courſe and baſe appetites earths meere inheritours
And heires of Idlenes and blood; Pure Love
That that the ſoule affects and cannot purchaſe
VVhile ſhe is loden with our fleſh, that love Sir
VVhich is the price of honour dwells not here,
Your Ladies eyes are lampleſſe to that vertue,
That beautie ſmiles not on a cheeke waſht over,
Nor ſents the ſweets of Ambers; below, Siphax
Below us, in the other VVord, Elizium,
VVher's no more dying, no deſpairing, mourning,
VVhere all deſires are full, deſerts downe loden,
There Siphax, there, where loves are ever living,

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: VVhy doe we love in this VVorld then?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: To preſerve it,
The maker loſt his worke els: but marke Siphax,
VVhat iſſues that love beares.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: VVhy Children Sir;
I never heard him talke thus; thus divinelie
And ſenſible before

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: It does ſo, Siphax,
Things like our ſelves, as ſenſuall vaine unvented
Bubles and breath of ayres, got with an itching
As bliſters are; and bred, as much corruption
Flowes from their lives, ſorrow conceives and ſhapes 'em
And oftentimes the deaths of thoſe we love moſt
The breeders bring them to the VVorld to curſe 'em,
Crying they weepe amongſt us like young Catts,
Cares and continuall croſſes keeping with 'em,
They make time old to tend them and experience
An aſſe they alter ſo; they grow and goodlie
'Ere we can turne our thoughts, like dropps of water
They fall into the maine, and knowne no more;
This is the love of this world: I muſt tell thee
For thou art underſtanding

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: What you pleaſe Sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: And as a faithfull man
Nay I dare truſt thee
I love the Princeſſe

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: There 'tis that has fired him
I knew he had ſome inſpiration
But does ſhe know it Sir?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Yes marry does ſhe
I have given my heart unto her

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: If ye love her

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Nay underſtand me, my heart taken from me
Out of my body man and ſo brought to her
How lik'ſt thou that braue offer? ther's the love
I told thee of; and after death the living;
She muſt in juſtice, come boye, ha?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Your heart Sir?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I, ſo by all meanes Siphax

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: He loves roſt well
That eates the ſpitt

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: And ſince thou art come thus fitlie
Ile doe it preſentlie and thou ſhall carrie it
For thou canſt tell a ſtorie and diſcribe it
And I coniure thee Siphax by thy gentrie
Next by the glorious battells we have fought in
By all the dangers, wounds, heats, colds, diſtreſſes,
Thy love next and obedience, nay thy life

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: But one thing firſt Sir, if ſhe pleas'd to grant it
Could ye not love her here and live, conſider

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Ha? yes I thinke I could

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: 'Twoul'd be far neerer
Beſides the ſweets here, would induce the laſt love
And linck it in

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Thou ſayeſt right, but our ranckes heere
And bloods are barrs between us, ſhe muſt ſtand off too
As I perceive ſhe does

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Deſert and dutie
Makes even all Sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Then the King, though I
Have merited as much as man can; muſt not let her,
So many Princes covetous of beautie;
I woo'd with all my heart but 'tis impoſſible

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Why ſay ſhe marry after

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: No ſhe dare not
The Gods dare not doe ill: come

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Doe you meane it

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Lend me thy knife, and helpe me of

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: For heav'n ſake
Be not ſo ſtupid mad deare Generall.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Diſpatch, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: As ye love that ye looke for
Heaven and the bleſſed life.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Hell take thee Coxcombe,
Why doſt thou keepe me from it; thy knife, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Doe but this one thing, on my knees I beg it,
Stay but two houres till I returne againe,
For I will to her, tell her all your merits,
Your moſt unvalu'd love, and laſt your danger;
If ſhee relent, then live ſtill, and live loving,
Happy, and high in favour: if ſhe frowne;

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Shall I be ſure to know it.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: As I live Sir,
My quick returne ſhall either bring ye fortune,
Or leave you to your owne fate.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Two houres?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Let it be kept, away, I will expect it. Exeunt Memnon Siphax.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: You dainty wits two, an ye to a Cater,
To cheat him of a dinner.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Ten at Court ſir
Are few enough, they are as wiſe as we are.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Hang ye, I'le eat at any time: and any where
I never make that part of want, preach to me
What ye can doe, and when ye liſt.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Your patience,
'Tis a hard day at Court, a fiſh day.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: So it ſeemes ſir,
The finns grow out of thy face.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: And to purchaſe
This day the company of one deare Cuſtard,
Or a meſſe of Rice ap Thomas, needs a maine wit;
Beefe we can beare before us linde with Brewes
And tubs of Porke; vociferating Veales,
And tongues that ne're told lye yet.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Line thy mouth with 'em

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Thou haſt need, and great need,
For theſe finny fiſh-dayes,
The Officers underſtandings are ſo flegmatick,
They cannot apprehend us.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: That's great pitty,
For you deſerve it, and being apprehended
The whip to boot; Boy what doe you ſo neare me,
I dare not truſt your touch boy.

div.stage: Enter Stremon and his Boy Ed. Hor.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: As I am vertuous
What, theeves among our ſelves?

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: Lievtenant.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Welcome aſhore, aſhore.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: What Monſieur, Muſicke?

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: My fine Foole.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Fellow Cracke, why what a conſort
Are we now bleſt withall?

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Fooling and fidling
Nay and we live not now boyes; what new ſongs ſirra.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: A thouſand man, a thouſand.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Itching ayres
Alluding to the old ſport.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: Of all ſizes.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: And how does ſmall Tym Treble here; the heart on't.

sp.speaker: Boy. 2.
sp.l: To doe you ſervice.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.l: O Tym the times, the times Tym.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: How does the Generall,
And next what moneys ſtirring?

sp.speaker: Chy.
sp.l: For the Generall
Is here, but ſuch a Generall
The times chang'd Stremon,
He was the liberall Generall, and the loving,
The feeder of a Souldier, and the father,
But now become the ſtupid'ſt.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: Why, what ailes he.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Nay, if a horſe knew, and his head's big enough
I'le hang for't; did'ſt thou ever ſee a dog
Run mad o'th' tooth-ache, ſuch another toy
Is he now ſo, a glotes and grins, and bites.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.l: Why hang him quickly,
And then he cannot hurt folkes.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: One houre raving,
Another ſmiling, not a word the third houre,
I tell thee Stremon has a ſtirring ſoule,
What ever it attempts or labours at
Would weare out twenty bodies in another.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.l: I'le keep it out of me, for mine's but buckeram,
Hee would bownce that out in two houres.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Then he talkes
The ſtrangeſt and the maddeſt ſtuffe from reaſon,
Or any thing ye offer; ſtand thou there,
I'le ſhow thee how he is, for I'le play Memnon
The ſtrangeſt Generall that ere thou heardſt of Stremon.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Goe preſently and find me
A black horſe with a blew taile; bid the blank Cornet
Charge through the Sea, and ſinke the Navy: ſoftly,
Our ſoules are things not to be waken'd in us
With larums, and lowd bawlings, for in Elizium
Stilneſſe and quietneſſe, and ſweetneſſe, ſirra,
I will have, for it much concernes mine honour,
Such a ſtrong reputation for my welcome
As all the world ſhall ſay: for in the forefront
So many on white Unicornes, next them
My gentlemen, my Cavaliers and Captaines,
Ten deep and trapt with tenter-hookes to take hold
Of all occaſions: for Friday cannot fiſh out
The end I aime at; tell me of Diocles,
And what he dare doe, dare he meet me naked
Thunder in this hand, in his left? Foole?

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Foole, I would have thee fly i'th' ayre fly ſwiftly
To that place where the Sun ſets, there deliver.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Deliver? what ſir?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: This ſir, this ye ſlave ſir, All laugh.
Death ye rude rogues, ye Scarrubbs.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Hold for Heav'ns ſake Lievtenant, ſweet Lievte|nant.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I have done ſir.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: You have wrung his neck off.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: No Boy, 'tis the nature
Of this ſtrange paſſion when't hits to hale people
Along by th'haire, to kick 'em, breake their heads:

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Do ye call this Acting, was your part to beat me.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Yes, I muſt act all that he does.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Plague act yee,
I'le act no more.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: 'Tis but to ſhew man.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Then man
Hee ſhould have ſhew'd it only, and not done it,
I am ſure he beat me beyond Action,
Gowts a your heavy fiſt.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Ile have thee to him,
Thou haſt a fine wit, fine foole, and canſt play rarely.
Hele hug thee, boy, and ſtroke thee,

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Ile to the ſtockes firſt,
'Ere I be ſtrokt thus.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: But how came he Chilax?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I know not that,

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Ile to him

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: He loves thee well,
And much delights to here thee ſing; much taken
He has bin with thy battell ſongs.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: If Muſique,
Can find his madnes; ile ſo fiddle a him,
That out it ſhall by'th ſhoulders,

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: My fine fidler,
Hele firke you and ye take not heed too: t'will be rare ſport
To ſee his owne trade triumph over him;
His Lute lac'd to his head, for creeping hedges;
For mony ther's none ſtirring; try good Stremon
Now what your ſilver ſound can doe; our voices
Are but vaine Ecchoes,

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Something ſhall be done
Shall make him underſtand all; lets to'th Taverne,
I have ſome few Crownes left yet: my whiſtle wet once
Ile pipe him ſuch a Paven -

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Hold thy head up,
Ie cure it with a quart of wine; Come Coxcombe;
Come boye take heed of napkins.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Youl'd no more acting?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: No more Chicken;

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Goe then.

div.stage: Enter Siphax at one Dore, and a Gentleman at another.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: God ſave you ſir; pray how might I ſee the Princeſs

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Why very fitly ſir ſhees even now ready,
To wa ke out this way into'th parke; ſtand there,
Ye cannot miſſe her ſight, ſir,

sp.speaker: Siphax.
sp.l: I much thanke ye.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Lets have a care, for ile aſſure ye wenches
I woo d not meet him willingly agen;
For though I doe not feare him, yet his faſhion
I wood not be acquainted much wit'h.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Gentle Ladie,
Ye need not feare the walkes are viewed and emptie,
But my thinkes Madam this kind heart of his —

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Is ſlow a coming.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Keepe me ye bleſt Angells,
What killing power is this?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: VVhy doſt thou looke for't?
Doſt thinke he ſpoke in earneſt?

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: My thinkes Madam,
A Gentleman ſhould keepe his word; and to a Ladie
A Ladie of your excellencies;

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Out foole!
Send me his heart? what ſhould we doe wo't? dance it?

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Drie it and drinke it for the wormes.

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: Whoſe that?
What man ſtands there?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: VVhere?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: There.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: A Gentleman,
Which I beſeech your grace to honour ſo much,
As know him for your ſervants brother.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: The ſame an't pleaſe your grace; what does he here?
Upon what buſines and I ignorant?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Hee's growne a handſome Gentleman; good Siphax
Yat wel-come from the warres; woo'd ye with us ſir?
Pray ſpeake your will: a bluſhes, be not fearefu l,
I can aſſure ye for your Siſters ſake ſir,
Ther's my hand on it.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Doe you heare Sir?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Sure theſe Souldiers,
Are all growne ſenſeles,

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Doe ye know where ye are ſir?

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: Tongue-tyde,
He lookes not well too, by my life, I thinke;

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Speake, for ſhame ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: A man woo'd ſpeake —

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Theſe Souldiers,
Are all dumb Saints: Conſider and take time ſir,
Lets forward wenches come, his pallats downe.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Dare theſe men charge it'h face of fire and bullets?
And hang there heads downe at a handſome Woman?
Good maſter Mars that 's a ſoule fault.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Fye beaſt,
No more my brother.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: Siſter, honoured Siſter,

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Diſhonoured foole,

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: I doe confeſſe,

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Fye on thee,

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: But ſtay till I deliver,

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Let me goe,
I am a ſhame to owne thee,

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Fare ye well then,
Ye muſt nere ſee me more,

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Why ſtay deare Siphax,
My angers paſt; I will heare ye ſpeake

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: O Siſter,

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Out with it Man,

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: O I have drunke my miſchiefe,

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Ha? what?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: My deſtruction.
In at mine eyes I have drunke it; O the Princeſs,
The rare ſweet Princeſs!

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: How foole? the rare Princeſs?
Was it the Princeſs that thou ſed'ſt?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: The Princeſs,

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Thou doeſt not love her ſure, thou darſt not.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Yes by heaven,

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Yes by Heaven? I know thou darſt not,
The Princeſs? 'tis thy life the knowledge of it,
Preſumption that will draw into it all thy kinred,
And leave 'em ſlaves and ſuccourles; the Princeſs?
Why ſhee's a ſacred thing to ſee and worſhip,
Fixt from us as the Sun is high and glorious,
To be ador'd not doated on; deſire things poſſible,
Thou fooliſh young man, nouriſh not a hope,
Will haile thy heart out.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: 'Tis my deſtinie,
And I know both diſgrace and death will quit it,
If it be knowne

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Purſue it not then Syphax
Get thee good wholeſome thoughts may nouriſh thee.
Goe home and pray

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: I cannot

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Sleep then Syphax.
And dreame away thy doting.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: I muſt have her
Or you no more your brother; worke Cleant he,
Worke, and worke ſpeedilie, or I ſhall die wench.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Dye then, I dare forget; farewell

sp.speaker: Syp.
sp.l: Farewell Siſter.
Farewell for ever, ſee me buried.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Stay.
Pray ſtay? hee's all my brothers: no way Siphax.
No other Woman,

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: None, none, ſhee or ſincking.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Goe and hope well, my life ile venture for thee
And all my art, a Woman may worke miracles;
No more, pray heartily againſt my fortunes,
For much I feare a maine one.

sp.speaker: Syphax.
sp.l: I ſhall doe it. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Prima.
div.stage: Enter a Prieſt of Venus and a Boye.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Find him by any meanes; and good child tell him
He has forgot his old friend, give him this,
And ſay this night without excuſe or buſines
As ever he may find a friend, come to me,
He knowes the way and how, begon.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I gallop. Exit Boy.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: I have bin looking you;

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: The faire Cleanthe,
VVhat may your buſines be?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: O holy Mother
Such buſines of ſuch ſtrange waite, now or never.
As ye have loved me, as ye doe or may doe,
When I ſhall find a fit time.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: If by my meanes
Your buſines may be fitted; ye know me,
And how I am tyed unto you; be bold daughter
To build your beſt hopes,

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: O but 'tis a ſtrange one
Stuck with as many dangers -

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Ther's the working,
Small things performe themſelves and give no pleaſures;
Be confident through death ile ſerve.

sp.speaker: Clean
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Fye no corruption

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Take it; 'tis yours,
Be not ſo ſpiced, 'tis good gold
And goodnes is no gall to'th conſcience,
I know you have wayes to vent it: ye may hold it

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Ile keep it for ye; when?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: To morrow morning
Ile viſit ye agen; and when occaſion
Offers it ſelfe -

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Inſtruct me, and have at ye -

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Farewell till then; be ſure.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: As your owne thoughts, Ladie.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: 'Tis a maine worke and full of feare.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Fooles only Exit Cle.
Make their effects ſeeme fearefull: farewell daughter.
This gold was well got for my old tuff Souldier
Now I ſhall be his ſweet agen; what buſines
Is this ſhe has a foote? ſome luſtie lover
Beyond her line, the young wench would faine piddle
A little to revive her, muſt be thought of,
'Tis even ſo; ſhe muſt have it; but how by my meanes
A devill can ſhe drive it? I that wait ſtill
Before the Goddeſſe giving Oracle
How can I profit her? 'tis her owne project,
And if ſhe caſt it falſe her owne fault be it. Exit. Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Why this is utter madnes

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Thus it is Sir

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Only the Princeſſe ſight?

sp.speaker: 1. Cap.
sp.l: All we can judge at;

sp.speaker: Poli.
sp.l: This muſt be loo'kt to timelie.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Yes and wiſelie;

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: He do's not offer at his life

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: not yet ſir
That we can heare of

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Noble Gentlemen;
Let me entreat your watches over him.
Ye cannot doe a worthier worke.

sp.speaker: 2. Cap.
sp.l: We came Sir
Provided for that ſervice?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Where is Chilax?

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: A little buſie Sir?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Is the foole and boye here.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: They are Sir,

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Let 'em be ſtill ſo; and as they find his humors

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Now ye may behold him

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Stand cloſe and worke no noyſe;
By his eyes now, Gentlemen,
I gueſſe him full of anger

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Be not ſeene there

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: The houre's paſt long agoe, hees falſe and fearefull,
Coward goe with thy catine ſoule, thou our dog.
Thou cold clod, wilde fire warme thee, monſtrous fearful,
I know the ſlave ſhakes but to thinke on't.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: VVhoſe that?

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: I know not Sir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: But I ſhall catch yee raſcall,
Your mangie ſoule is not immortall here Sir,
Ye muſt die, and we muſt meet; we muſt, maggot,
Be ſure we muſt, for not a nooke of hell,
Not the moſt horrid pit ſhall harbour thee.
The Devills taile ſhall hide thee, but ile have thee,
And how ile uſe thee, whips and firebrands
Toſting thy taile againſt a flame of wilde fire,
And baſting it with brimſtone, ſhall be nothing,
Nothing at all; ile reach ye to be treacherous;
Was never ſlave ſo ●wing'd ſince hell was hell
As I will ſwinge thy ſlaves ſoule: and be ſure on't.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Is this imagination, or ſome circumſtance
For 'tis extreame ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: So is all he does Sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Till then ile leave ye? whoſe there? wheres the Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: My Lord,

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Bring the Surgeon.
And waite you too. Enter Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Poli.
sp.l: What wood ye with a Surgeon

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: Things muſtring in his head: pray marke

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Come hither.
Have you brought your Inſtruments.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: They are within Sir,

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Put to the doores a while there; ye can inciſe
To a haires bredth without defacing;

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Yes ſir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: And take out fairely from the fleſh;

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: The leaſt thing.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Well, come hither then; take off my doublet,
●or looke ye Surgeon, I muſt have ye cut
My Heart out here, and handſomly: Nay, ſtare not,
Nor doe not ſtart; I'le cut your throat elſe Surgeon,
Come ſweare to doe it.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: Good ſir—

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Sirra, hold him,
I'le have but one blow at his head.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: I'le doe it,
Why what ſhould we doe living after you ſir?
Wee'le die before if yee pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: No, No.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: Living? hang living,
Is there ne're a Cat hole where I may creep through?
Woo'd I were in the Indies.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Sweare then, and after my death preſently
To kill your ſelves and follow, as ye are honeſt,
As ye have faiths and loves to me.

sp.speaker: Dema.
sp.l: Wee'l doe it.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Pray doe not ſtir yet, we are neare enough
To run between all dangers.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Here I am ſir;
Come looke upon me, view the beſt way boldly,
Feare nothing but cut home; if your hand ſhake ſirra,
Or any way deface my heart i'th' cutting,
Make the leaſt ſcratch upon it, but draw it whole,
Excellent faire, ſhewing at all points, Surgeon,
The honour and the valour of the owner,
Mixt with the moſt immaculate love I ſend it,
Looke too't, I'le ſlice thee to the ſoule.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Ne're feare ſir,
I'le doe it daintily; would I were out once.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I will not have ye ſmile ſirra when ye do it,
As though ye cut a Ladies corne; tis ſcurvie;
Doe me it as thou doſt thy praiers, ſeriouſly.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: I'le doe it in a dump ſir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: In a dog ſir,
I'le have no dumps, nor dumplins: fetch your tooles,
And then I'le tell ye more.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: If I returne
To heare more I'le be hang'd for't.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Quick, quick.

sp.speaker: Dema.
sp.l: Yes ſir,
With all the heeles we have, Exeunt Surgeon. Demago|ras.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Yet ſtand.

sp.speaker: Poli.
sp.l: Hee'le doe it.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: He cannot and we here.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Why when ye raſcalls,
Ye dull ſlaves: will ye come ſir? Surgeon, Serring,
Dogleach, ſhall I come fetch ye?

sp.speaker: Poli.
sp.l: Now i'le to him,
God ſave ye honour'd brother

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: My deare Polidor,
Welcome from travell welcome; and how doe ye?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Well ſir, would you were ſo.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I am, I thanke ye,
You are a better'd man much, I the ſame ſtill,
An old rude Souldier, ſir.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Pray be plaine brother,
And tell me but the meaning of this viſion,
For to me it appeares no more: ſo farre
From common courſe and reaſon.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Thanke thee Fortune,
At length I have found the man: the man muſt do it,
The man in honour bound.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: To doe what?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Harke, for I will bleſſe ye with the circumſtance
Of that weak ſhaddow that appear'd.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Speake on ſir. Walkes with him.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: It is no ſtorie for all eares.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: The Princeſſe?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Peace and heare all: how:

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Sure 'tis dangerous
He ſtarts ſo at it,

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Your heart, doe ye know ſir?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Yes, pray thee be ſofter.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Me to doe it?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Only Reſerv'd, and dedicated.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: For ſhame brother
Know, what, ye are, a man.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: None of your Athens
Good ſweet ſir, no Philoſophy, thou feel'ſt not
The honourable end, foole.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I am ſure I feele
The ſhame & ſcorn that follows; have ye ſerv'd thus long
The glory of your Country, in your Conqueſts,
The envy of your neighbours, in your vertues,
Rul'd Armies of your owne, given Lawes to Nations,
Belov'd and fear'd as far as Fame has travel'd,
Call'd the moſt fortunate and happy Memnon,
To looſe all here at home, poorely to looſe it,
Poorely and pettiſhly, ridiculouſly
To fling away your fortune? where's your wiſdome?
Where's that you govern'd others by, diſcretion?
Do's your Rule laſtly hold upon your ſelfe? fie brother,
How are ye falne? get up into your honour
The top branch of your bravery, and from thence
Looke and lament how little Memnon ſeemes now.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Hum! tis well ſpoken; but do'ſt thou think, young ſcholler
The tongues of Angels from my happineſſe
Could turne the end I aime at? no: they cannot;
This is no booke caſe brother: will ye doe it?
Uſe no more art, I am reſolv'd.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Ye may, ſir
Command me to doe any thing that's honeſt,
And for your noble end: but this it carries.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Ye ſhall not be ſo honour'd; live an Aſſe ſtill,
And learne to ſpell for profit: goe, goe ſtudie.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Ye muſt not hold him up ſo, he is loſt then.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Get thee to ſchoole agen, and talke of turnips,
And find the naturall cauſe out, why a dog
Turnes thrice about e're he ly downe: there's learning.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Come, I will doe it now; 'tis brave, I find it,
And now allow the reaſon.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: O doe ye ſo ſir,
Doe ye find it currant?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Yes, yes, excellent.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I told ye.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I was fooliſh: I have here too
The rareſt way to find the truth out; hark ye,
Ye ſhall be rul'd by me.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I will be: but—

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: I reach it,
If the worſt fall, have at the worſt: wee'le both goe
But two dayes, and 'tis thus; ha?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: 'Twill doe well ſo

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Then if not excellent, doe ye conceive it

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: 'Twill worke for certaine A bowle ready.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: O 'twill tickle her
And you ſhall know then by a line

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I like it
But let me not be fool'd againe

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Doubt nothing
You doe me wrong then, get ye in there privat
As I have taught ye; Baſta

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Worke (Exit Memnon.)

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I will doe

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Have ye found the cauſe

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Yes, and the ſtraingeſt, Gentlemen,
That ere I heard of, anon ile tell ye; Stremon
Be you ſtill neere him to affect his fancie
And keepe his thoughts off: Let the Foole and Boy
Stay him, they may doe ſome pleaſure too; Eumenes
VVhat if he had a wench, an handſome whore brought
Rarely dreſt up, and taught to ſtate it?

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: VVell Sir

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: His cauſe is meerly heat: and made beleeve
It were the Princeſſe mad for him,

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: I thinke
'Twere not amiſſe.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.l: And let him kiſſe her

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: VVhat els?

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.l: Ile be his bawde ant pleaſe you, young and holeſome
I can aſſure ye he ſhall have

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Faith let him

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: A ſhall, I hope 'twill helpe him, walke a little
Ile tell you how his caſe ſtands, and my project
In which you muſt be mourners, but by all meanes
Stir not you from him: Stremon.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.p: On our Lives Sir Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Prieſt.
sp.l: O y'ar a pretious Man; two daies in towne
And neuer ſee your old friend?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Prithe pardon me

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: And in my conſcience if I had not ſent

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: No more I would a come; I muſt

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I find ye
God a mercy want ye never care for me
But when your ſlops are emptie

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Nere feare that wench
Shall find good currant coyne ſtill; is this the old houſe?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Have ye forgot it?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: And the dore ſtill ſtanding
That goes into the Temple?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Still.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: The Robes to,
That I was wount to ſhift in here?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: All here ſtill.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: O ye tuff rogue what troubles have I trotted through?
VVhat feares and frights, every poore mouſe a monſter
That I heard ſtir, and every ſtick I trod on
A ſharp ſting to my conſcience

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Las poore conſcience,

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: And all to liquor thy old bootes wench

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Out beaſt!

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: To new carine thy carkas, that's the truth on't
How does thy keele? does it need nayling? a tother
VVhen all thy linnen's up: and a more yare?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Fye Fye Sir

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Nere ſtem'd the ſtraights?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: How you talke?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I am old wench,
And talking to an old Man is like a ſtomacher
It keepes his blood warme

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: But; pray tell me

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Any thing

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Where did the boy meet with ye, at a wench ſure,
At one end of a wench, a Cup of wine ſure

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Thou know'ſt I am too honeſt

sp.speaker: Prieſt.
sp.l: That's your fault
And that the Surgeon knowes

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Then farewell
I will not faile ye ſoone

sp.speaker: Prieſt.
sp.l: Ye ſhall ſtaye Supper
I have ſworne ye ſhall, by this ye ſhall

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I will wench,
But after Supper for an houre, my buſines

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: And but an houre

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: No by this kiſſe, that ended
I will returne and all night in thine Armes wench

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: No more, ile take your meaning; come 'tis Supper time

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: Thou art not well

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Your grace ſees more a great deale
Then I feele (yet I lye) o brother ●

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Marke her,
Is not the quicknes of her ey conſumed, wench?
The livelye red and white?

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Nay ſhe is much alter'd
That on my underſtanding, all her ſleep's Ladie
Which were as ſound and ſweet

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Pray doe not force me
Good Madam where I am not, to be ill,
Conceit's a double ſicknes; on my faith your highnes
Is meere miſtaken in me A Dead March within of Drum and Sagbutts

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I am glad on't
Yet this I have ever noted when thou waſt thus
It ſtill forerun ſome ſtrange event: my Siſter
Died when thou waſt thus laſt: harke harke ho,
What mournefull noyſe is this comes creeping forward,
Still it growes neerer, neerer, do ye heare it?

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: It ſeemes ſome Souldiers funerall: ſee it enters

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: What may it meane?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: The Gods keep ye faire Calis

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: This man can ſpeake, and well; a ſtands and views us
Woo'd I were nere worſe look't upon: how humbly
His eyes are caſt now to the earth: pray marke him
And marke how rarely he has ranckt his troubles:
See now a weepes, they all weep; a ſweeter ſorrow
I never look't upon nor one that braver
Became his griefe; your will with us.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Great Ladie Plucks out the Cup.
Excellent beauty

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: He ſpeakes handſomelie
What a rare rhetorician his greif plaies,
That ſtop was admirable

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: See ſee thou Princeſſe
Thou great commander of all hearts

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I have found it,
Oh how my ſoule ſhakes:

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: See, ſee the noble hart
Of him that was the nobleſt: ſee and glory
Like the proud God himſelfe in what thou haſt purchas'd
Behold the heart of Memnon: does it ſtart ye?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Good gods, what has his wildenes done?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Looke boldlie
You boldlie ſed you durſt looke wretched woman,
Nay flie not back faire follie, 'tis too late now
Vertue and blooming honour bleed to death here,
Take it the Legacie of Love bequeath'd ye,
Of cruell Love, a cruell Legacie;
What was the will that wrought it? then can ye weepe?
Imbalme it in your trueſt teares?
If Women can weepe a truth, or ever ſorrow ſunck yet
Into the ſoule of your ſex, for 'tis a Jewell
The VVorlds worth cannot weigh downe,
Take it Ladie; And with it all (I dare not curſe) my ſorrowes
And may they turne to Serpents.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: How ſhe lookes
Still upon him: ſee now a teare ſteales from her

sp.speaker: 2. Cap.
sp.l: But ſtill ſhe keepes her ey firme

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Next read this,
But ſince I ſee your ſpirit ſomewhat troubled
Ile doe it for ye

sp.speaker: 2. Cap.
sp.p:
Still ſhe eyes him mainlie
Goe happy heart for thou ſhalt ly
Intomb'd in her for whom I dy
Example of her cruelty.
Tell her if ſhe chance to chide
Me for ſlownes in her pride
That it was for her I died.
If a teare eſcape her eye
'Tis not for my memory.
But thy rights of obſequy
The Altar was my loving breſt
My heart the ſacrificed beaſt
And I was my ſelfe the Preiſt
Your body was the ſacred ſhrine
Your cruell mind the power divine
Pleas'd with hearts of men not kine

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Now it poures downe

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I like it rarelie Ladie

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: How greedily ſhe ſwallowes up his language?

sp.speaker: 2. Cap.
sp.l: Her eye inhabits on him

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Cruell Ladie,
Great as your beautie ſcornefull; had your power
But equall poiſe on all hearts; all hearts periſh't;
But Cupid has more ſhafts then one more flames too
And now he muſt be open ey'd, 'tis Juſtice:
Live to injoye your longing; live and laugh at
The loſſes and the miſeries we ſuffer;
Live to be ſpoken when your crueltie
Has cut of all the vertue from this Kingdome
Turned honour into earth, and faithfull ſervice

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I ſweare his angers excellent

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Truth and moſt tried love
Into diſdaine and downefall,

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: Still more pleaſing,

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Live then I ſay famous for civill ſlaughters,
Live and lay out your triumphs, guild your glories
Live and be ſpoken this is ſhe this Ladie,
This goodly Ladie, yet moſt killing beautie;
This with the two edg'd eyes, the heart for hardnes
Out doing rockes; and coldnes, rockes of Chriſtall
This with the ſwelling ſoule, more coye of Courtſhip
Then the proud ſea is when the ſhores embrace him
Live till the mothers find ye; read your ſtory
And ſowe their barren curſes on your beauty,
Till thoſe that have enjoy'd their loves deſpiſe ye,
Till Virgins pray againſt ye, old age find ye
And even as waſted coales glow in their dying
So may the Gods reward ye in your aſhes:
But y'ar the Siſter of my King; more propheſies
Els I ſhould utter of ye true loves and loyall
Bleſſe themſelves ever from ye: ſo I leave ye

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: Prithee be angry ſtill young man: good faire Sir
Chide me againe, what woo●d this man doe pleas'd,
That in his paſſions can bewitch ſoules ſtay,

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Upon my life ſhe loves him

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: Pray ſtay

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: No

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I doe command ye

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: No, ye cannot Ladie
I have a ſpell againſt yee, Faith and Reaſon,
Yee are to weak to reach me: I have a heart too,
But not for hawkes meat Ladie

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Even for Charity
Leave me not thus aflicted: you can teach me

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: How can you Preach that Charitie to others
That in your owne ſoule are an Athieſt
Beleeving neither power nor feare: I trouble ye,
The Gods be good unto ye.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Amen.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Ladie, She Swounes

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: O royall Madam, Gentlemen for heav'n ſake, They come back.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Give her freſh air ſhe comes again: away ſirs
And here ſtand cloſe till we perceive the working

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Ye have undone all

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: So I feare

sp.speaker: 2. Cap.
sp.l: She loves ye

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: And then all hopes loſt this way

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Peace ſhe riſes

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Now for my purpoſe Fortune

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: Wher's the Gentleman

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Gone Madam

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Why gone?

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Has diſpatch't his buſines

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: A came to ſpeake with me
A did,

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: A did not

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: For I had many queſtions

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: On my Faith Madam, he
Talk't a great while to ye

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Thou conceiv'ſt not.
He talk't not as he ſhould doo; o my heart
Away with that ſad ſight; didſt thou ere love me?

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Why doe you make that queſtion?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: If thou didſt
Run run wench, run: nay ſee how thou ſtir'ſt

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Whither?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: If 'twer for any thing to pleaſe thy ſelfe
Thou wood'ſt run to'th devill: but I am growne

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Fie Ladie

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I aſke none of your fortunes, nor your loves
None of your bent deſires I ſlack, ye are not
In love with all men, are ye? one for ſhame
You will leave your honour'd miſtris? why doe ye ſtare ſo
What is that ye ſee about mee, tell me;
Lord what am I become? I am not wilde ſure,
Heaven keepe that from me: o Cleanthe help me
Or I am ſuncke to death

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Ye have offended and mightily, love is incenſt againſt yee
And therefore take my Councell, to the Temple
For that's the ſpeedieſt phyſick: before the Goddeſſe
Give your repentant prayers: aske her will
And from the Oracle attend your ſentence
She is milde and mercifull

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: I will: o Venus
Even as thou lov'ſt thy ſelfe!

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: Now for my fortune Exeunt Calis and Women.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: What ſhall I doe?

sp.speaker: 1. Cap.
sp.l: VVhy make your ſelfe

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: I dare not,
No Gentlemen, I dare not be a villaine
Though her bright beauty would entice an Angell
I will to'th King my laſt hope: get him a Woman
As we before concluded: and as ye paſſe
Give out the Spartans are in armes; and terrible
And let ſome letters to that end be fain'd too
And ſent to you, ſome Poets too, to the Generall
And let me worke: be nere him ſtill,

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: We will Sir

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Farwell: and pray for all: what 'ere I will ye
Doe it, and hope a faire end

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: The Gods ſpeed ye. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Stremon Foole, Boy, and Servants.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.l: He lies quiet

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Let him lye and as I told ye
Make ready for this ſhew: h'as divers times
Been calling upon Orpheus to appeare
And ſhew the joyes: now I wilbe that Orpheus,
And as I play and ſing like beaſts and trees
I woo'd have you ſhapt and enter: thou a Dog, foole,
I have ſent about your ſutes: the Boy a buſh,
An Aſſe you, you a Lion

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: I a dog?
Ile fit you for a Dog. Bow wow

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: 'Tis excellent
Steale in and make no noiſe

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Bow wow

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Away rogue. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Prieſt.
sp.l: Good ſweet friend be not long

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Thou think'ſt each houre ten
Till I be ferreting

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: You know I love ye

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I will not be above an houre; let thy robe be readie
And the doore be kept Knock.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Who knocks there? Cleanthe knocks within.
Yet more buſines?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Have ye more penſioners, the Princeſſe woman?
Nay then ile ſtay a little, what games a foote now?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Now is the time

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: A rancke bawde by this hand, too
She grinds a both ſides: hey boyes

sp.speaker: Prieſt.
sp.l: How your brother Siphax?
Loves he the Princeſſe?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Deadlie, and you know
He is a Gentleman deſcended noblie.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: But a ranck knave as ever piſt

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: ●old Mother
Heres more gold and ſome jewells

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Heres no villany
I am glad I came to'th hearing

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Alas Daughter,
What would ye have me doe?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Hold off ye old whore;
Ther's more gold comming; alls mine, all

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Doe ye ſhrink now,
Did ye not promiſe faithfully and told me
Through any danger?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Any I can wade through

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Ye ſhall, and eaſilie the ſin not ſeene neither
Heres for a better ſtole and a new vaile mother
Come ye ſhall be my friend: if all hit

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Hang me
Ile make ye richer then the Goddeſſe.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Say then
I am yours, what muſt I doe?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I'th morning
But very early, will the Princeſſe viſit
The Temple of the Goddeſſe, being troubled
With ſtrange things that diſtract her: from the Oracle
(Being ſtrongly too in love) ſhe will demand
The Goddeſſe pleaſure, and a Man to cure her,
That Oracle you give: deſcribe my Brother
You know him perfectly.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I have ſeene him often

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: And charge her take the next man ſhe ſhall meet with
When ſhe comes out; you underſtand me

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: VVell.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Which ſhalbe he attending; this is all
And eaſily without ſuſpition ended,
Nor none dare diſobey, 'tis Heaven that does it,
And who dares croſſe it then, or once ſuſpect it?
The venture is moſt eaſie.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I will doe it.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: As ye ſhall proſper;

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: As I ſhall proſper.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Take this too, and farewell; but firſt harke hither.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: What a young whores this to betray her miſtris?
A thouſand Cuckolds ſhall that husband be,
That marries thee, thou art ſo miſchievous.
Ile put a ſpoke among your wheeles

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Be conſtant

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: 'Tis done

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.p: Ile doe no more at drop ſhot then Exit Chilax.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Farewell wench. Exeunt Prieſt and Cleanthe

div.head: Scaena Prima.
div.stage: Enter a Servant and R. Bax, and Stremon at the doore.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.l: A ſtirs a ſtirs

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Let him, I am ready for him,
He ſhall not this day periſh, if his paſſions
May bee fed with Muſick; are they ready

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: All, all: ſee where he comes

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Ile be ſtraight for him. Exit Stremon.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: How ſad he lookes and ſullen. Stand cloſe.
Here are the Captaines: my feares paſt now.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Put caſe i'th other world
She doe not love me neither: I am old 'tis certaine

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: His ſpirit is a little quieter.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: My blood loſt and my limbes ſtif; my embraces
Like the cold ſtubborne ba●kes ●hoa●ie and hear●es
My words worſe: my fame only and atcheivements
Which are my ſtrength, my blood, my youth my faſhion,
Muſt woe her, win her, wed her; that's but wind
And Women are not brought to bed with ſhadowes:
I doe her wrong, much wrong; ſhe is young and bleſſed,
