Sweet as the ſpring, and as his bloſſomes tender,
And I a nipping north wind, my head ●ung
With hailes, and froſtie Iſicles: are the ſoules ſo too
When they depart hence, lame and old, and love les?
No ſure, 'tis ever youth there; Time and Death
Follow our fleſh no more: and that forc'd opinion
That Spirits have no ſexes, I beleive not
There muſt be love, there is love? what art thou.

lg.l: Orpheus, I am come from the deep's below,
To thee fond man the plagues of love to ſhow:
To the faire fields where loves eternall dwell
Ther's none that came, but firſt they paſſe through hell:
Harke and beware unleſſe thou haſt loved ever,
Beloved againe, thou ſhalt ſee thoſe joyes never.
Hark how they graone that dyed deſpairing,
Hark how they houle for over daring
They that be fooles, and dye for fame
Now in cold froſts now ſcorching fires,
They ſit and curſe their loſt deſires:
Nor ſhall theſe ſoules be free from paines and feares,
Till Women waſt them over in their teares.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: How ſhould I know my paſſage is deni'de me
Or which of all the Devills dare

sp.speaker: Eumon.
sp.l: This Song
Was rarely formed to fit him.

sp.speaker: Orph.
sp.l: Charon o Charon
Thou wafter of the ſoules to bliſſe or bant

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Who calls the Fery man of Hell?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Come near
And ſay who lives in joye, and whom in feare.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Thoſe that dye well; Eternall joy ſhall follow,
Thoſe that dye ill; their owne ſoule ſaie ſhall ſwallow.

sp.speaker: Orph.
sp.l: Shall thy black Bark thoſe guilty ſpirits ſtow
That kill themſelves for love?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: O no no.
My cordage crackes when ſuch great ſins are neare
No winde blowes faire, nor I my ſelfe can ſteare

sp.speaker: Orph.
sp.l: What lovers paſſe and in Elizium raigne?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Thoſe gentle loves that are belov'd againe.

sp.speaker: Orph.
sp.l: This Souldier Loves, and faine wood dye to win,
Shall he goe on?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: No 'tis too foule a ſin
He muſt not come a boord: I dare not rowe,
Stormes of deſpaire and guilty blood will blowe.

sp.speaker: Orph.
sp.l: Shall time releaſe him ſaye?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: No, no, no no.
Nor time nor death can alter us, nor prayer;
My boate is de and who then d●re
But thoſe appointed come aboord Live ſtill,
And love by reaſon mor●all not by will,

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: And when thy Miſtris ſhall cloſe up thine eyes

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Then come a boord and paſſe,

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Till when be wiſe

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Till when be wiſe.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: How ſtill he ſitts: I hope this Song has ſetled him

sp.speaker: 1. Cap.
sp.l: He ●ites his lipp, and rowl●● his fierce eyes yet
I feare for all this

sp.speaker: 2. Cap.
sp.l: Stremon ſtill apply to him;

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Give me more roome then, ſweetlie ſtrike divinely
Such ſtraines and old earth moves at

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: The power I have over both Beaſt and plant
Thou man alone feelſt miſerable want Muſic.
Strike your rare Spirits that attend my will,
And looſe your ſavage wildneſſe by my skill.
This Lion was a man of Warre that died,
As thou wouldſt doe to guild her Ladies pride
This Dog a foole that hung himſelfe for love:
This Ape with daily hugging of a glove,
Forgot to eat and died. This goodly tree,
An uſher that ſtill grew before his Ladie,
Wither'd at roote. This, for he could not wooe,
A grumbling Lawyer: This pyed Bird a page,
That melted out becauſe he wanted age.
Still theſe lye houling on the ſtigian ſhore,
O love no more, o love no more.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: He ſteales off ſilently, as though he would ſleep,
No more but all be nere him, feed his fancie
Good Stremon ſtill; this may lock up his follie.
Yet Heaven knowes I muſt feare him; away ſoftly.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Did I not doe moſt doggedly?

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Moſt rarelie?

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Hee's a brave man when ſhall we dog agen;

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Unty me firſt for Gods ſake,

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Helpe the Boye; hee's in a wood poore child: good honny Stremon
Lets have a beare baiting; ye ſhall ſee me play.
The rareſt for a ſingle Dog: at head all;
And if I doe not win immortall glorie,
Play, Dog play Devill.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Peace for this time,

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Prithee.
Lets ſing him a blacke Santis, then lets all howle,
In our owne beaſtly voices; tree keepe your time,
Untye there; bow, wow, wow.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: A way ye Aſſe, away,

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: VVhy let us doe ſomething,
To ſatisfie the Gentleman, hee's mad;
A Gentleman like humour and in faſhion,
And muſt have men as mad about him.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Peace
And come in quicklie, 'tis ten to one els
Heel find a ſtaffe to beat a dog; no more words,
Ile get ye all imployment; ſoft ſoft in all, Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: VVhen cameſt thou over wench?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: But now this evening.
And have bin ever ſince looking out Siphax,
Ith' warres he would have lookt me: ſure has gotten
Some other Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: A thouſand wench, a thouſand
They are as common here as Caterpillers
Among the corne, they eat up all the Souldiers,

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Are they ſo hungry? yet by their leave Chilax,
Ile have a ſnatch too.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Doſt thou love him ſtill wench?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Why ſhould I not? he had my Maiden head
And all my youth.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Thou art come the happieſt
In the moſt bleſſed time, ſweet wench the fitteſt,
If thou darſt make thy fortune: by this light Cloe
And ſo ile kiſs thee: and if thou wilt but let me,
For 'tis well worth a kindnes.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: What ſhood I let ye?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Enjoye thy miniken

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Thou art ſtill old Chilax.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Still ſtill and ever ſhalbe: if, I ſay,
Thou wo't ſtrike the ſtroke: I cannot doe much harme wench

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Nor much good

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Siphax ſhall be thy Husband,
Thy very Husband woman, thy foole thy Cuckold,
Or what thou wilt make him: I am over joy'd,
Raviſht cleane raviſht with this fortune; kiſs me,
Or I ſhall looſe my ſelf,

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: My Husband ſed ye?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Sed I? and will ſay Cloe; nay and doe it
And doe it home to; Peg thee as cloſe to him
As birdes are with a pinne to one another;
I have it I can doe it: thou wants clothes too,
And heel be hanged unles he marry thee
Ere he maintaine thee: now he has Ladies Courtiers
More then his back can bend at? multitudes
We are taken up for threſhers, will ye bite?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Yes

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: And let me -

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Yes and let ye -

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: What!

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: VVhy that ye wo't of.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: The turne the good turne?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Any turne the Roche turne;

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: That's the right turne for that turnes up the bellie.
I cannot ſtay take your inſtructions
And ſomething toward howſhold, come, what ever
I ſhall adviſe ye follow it exactlie
And keep your times I point ye; for ile tell ye
A ſtrange way you muſt wade through.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Feare not me Sir.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Come then and lets diſpatch this modicum
For I have but an howre to ſtay, a ſhort one
Beſides more water for another mill
An old weake over ſhot I muſt provide for,
Ther's an old Nunnerie at hand.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: VVhat's that

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: A bawdie Houſe.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: A pox conſume it

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: If the ſtones ('tis bui●t on)
Were but as brickle as the fleſh lives in it,
Your curſe came handſomlie: feare not, ther's Ladies,
And other good ſad people: your pinkt Citizens
That thinke no ſhame to ſhake a ſheet there: Come wench

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: A Souldier and ſo fearefull?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Can ye blame me;
VVhen ſuch a waite lies on me?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Fye upon ye
I tell ye, ye ſhall have her: have her ſafelie,
And for your wife with her owne will,

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Good Siſter-

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: What a diſtruſtfull man are you? to morrow,
To morrow morning -

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Is it poſſible?
Can there be ſuch a happines?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Why hang me
If then ye be not married: if to morrow night,
Ye doe not -

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: O deare Siſter -

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: What ye woo'd doe
What ye deſire to doe; lie with her: Devill,
What a dull man are you?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Nay I believe now,
And ſhall ſhe love me?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: As her life and ſtroke ye,

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: O I will be her ſervant,

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: 'Tis your dutie,

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: And ſhe ſhall have her whole will,

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Yes 'tis reaſon,
She is a Princes, and by that rule boundles

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: What wood' you be, for I woo'd have ye Siſter
Chuſe ſome great place about us: as her woman
Is not ſo fit.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: No, no, I ſhall find places:

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: And yet to be a Ladie of her bedchamber,
I hold not ſo fit neither,
Some great title, beleeve it ſhall be look't out.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Ye may a Dutcheſſe
Or ſuch a toye, a ſmall thing pleaſes me Sir

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: What you will Siſter: if a neighbour Prince,
When we ſhall come to raigne -

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: We ſhall thinke on't,
Be ready at the time and in that place too,
And let me worke the reſt, within this half houre;
The Princeſs will be going, 'tis almoſt morning
Away and mind your buſines,

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Fortune bleſſe us. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I doe beſeech your grace to baniſh me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why Gentleman is ſhe not worthy marriage?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Moſt worthy, Sir, where worth againe ſhall meet her,
But I like thicke clouds ſailing ſlow and heavy,
Although by her drawne higher, yet ſhall hide her
I dare not be a traitor; and 'tis treaſon,
But to imagin: as you love your honour —

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: 'Tis her firſt maiden doting and if croſt,
I know it kills her.

sp.speaker: 1 Lord.
sp.l: How knowes your grace ſhe loves him?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Her woman told me all; beſide his ſtory
Her maid Lucippe on what reaſon to,
And tis beyond all but enjoying.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Sir.
Even by your wiſedome; by that great diſcretion
Ye owe to rule and order —

sp.speaker: 2 Lord.
sp.l: This man's mad ſure,
To plead againſt his fortune -

sp.speaker: 1 Lord.
sp.l: And the King too,
Willing to have it ſo?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: By thoſe dead Princes
From whoſe deſcents ye ſtand a ſtarre admired at,
Lay not ſo baſe a lay upon your vertues
Take heed for honours ſake take heed: the bramble
No wiſe man ever planted by the roſe,
It canckers all her beauty; nor the vine
When her full bluſhes courts the ſun dares any
Choke up with wanton Ivy? good my Lords,
Who builds a monument, the Baſis Jaſper,
And the maine body Brick?

sp.speaker: 2 Lord.
sp.l: Ye wrong your worth,
Ye are a Gentleman deſcended nobly.

sp.speaker: 1 Lord.
sp.l: In both bloods truly noble.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Say ye were not,
My will can make ye ſo.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: No, never, never;
'Tis not deſcent, nor will of Princes does it,
'Tis Vertue which I want, 'tis Temperance,
Man, honeſt man is't fit your Majeſty
Should call my drunkenneſſe, my raſhneſſe brother?
Or ſuch a bleſſed Maid my breach of faith,
For I am moſt lacivious; and fell angers
In which I am alſo miſchievous, her husband?
O Gods preſerve her! I am wild as Winter,
Ambitious as the Devill: out upon me,
I hate my ſelfe, ſir, if ye dare beſtow her
Upon a Subject ye have one deſerves her.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: But him ſhe does not love: I know your meaning.
This young mans love unto his noble brother,
Appeares a mirrour; what muſt now be done Lords?
For I am gravel'd, if ſhe have not him
She dies for certaine, if his brother miſſe her,
Farewell to him, and all our honours.

sp.speaker: 1 Lord.
sp.l: He is dead ſir,
Your Grace has heard of that, and ſtrangely.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No,
I can aſſure ye no there was a trick in't,
Read that, and then know all; what ailes the gentleman?
Hold him; how doe ye ſir? Polidor is ſick ath' ſudden.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Sick ath' the ſudden,
Extreamly ill, wondrous ill.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Where did it take ye?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Here in my head ſir, and my heart, for heaven ſake.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Conduct him to his chamber preſently,
And bid my Doctors—

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: No I ſhall be well ſir,
I doe beſeech your Grace even for the Gods ſake
Remember my poore brother, I ſhall pray then.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Away he growes more weaker ſtill: I will do it,
Or heaven forget me ever. Now your Counſells, Exit. Polidor.
For I am at my wits end; what with you ſir?

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: Letters from warlike Pelius.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yet more troubles?
The Spartans are in Armes, and like to win all:
Supplies are ſent for and the Generall;
This is more croſſe then tother; come let's to him,
For he muſt have her, 'tis neceſſitie,
Or we muſt loſe our honours, let's plead all,
For more then all is needfull, ſhew all reaſon
If love can heare a that ſide, if ſhe yeild
We have fought beſt and won the nobleſt field. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.l: I have brought the wench, a luſty wench,
And ſomewhat like the Princeſſe.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: 'Tis the better, let's ſee her,
And goe you in and tell him, that her Grace
Is come to viſit him? how ſleeps he Stremon?

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: He cannot, only thinkes, and calls on Polidor,
Swears a will not be fool'd; ſometimes he rages,
And ſometimes ſits and muſes. Exit. Stre.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: He's paſt all helpe ſure?
How doe ye like her?

sp.speaker: 2 Capt.
sp.l: Byth' maſſe a good round Virgin,
And at firſt ſight reſembling, ſhe is well cloth'd too.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: But is ſhe ſound?

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.l: Of wind and limbe, I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: You are inſtructed Lady?

sp.speaker: Who.
sp.l: Yes, and know ſir
How to behave my ſelfe, ne're feare.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: Where did he get this Vermin?

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.l: Hang him Badger,
There's not a hole free from him, whores and whores mates,
Doe all pay him obedience.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: Indeed i'th' war,
His quarter was all whore, whore upon whore,
And linde with a whore, beſhrew me 'tis a faire whore.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.l: She has ſmockt away her blood; but fair or foule,
Or blind or lame, that can but lift her leg up
Comes not amiſſe to him, he rides like a night mare,
All ages, all Religions.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: Can ye ſtate it?

sp.speaker: Who.
sp.l: I'le make a ſhift.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: He muſt lie with ye, Lady.

sp.speaker: Who.
sp.l: Let him, he's not the firſt man I have lain with,
Nor ſhall not be the laſt.

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.l: A comes, no more words,
She has her leſſon throughly; how he views her?

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Goe forward now, ſo, bravely, ſtand!

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Great Lady,
How humbly I am bound—

sp.speaker: Who.
sp.l: You ſhall not kneele ſir,
Come, I have done you wrong; ſtand up my Souldier,
And thus I make amends — Kiſſes him.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: A plague confound ye,
Is this your ſtate?

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.l: 'Tis well enough.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: O Lady,
Your royall hand, your hand my deareſt beauty
Is more then I muſt purchaſe: here divine one,
I dare revenge my wrongs: ha?

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.l: A dam'd foule one.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: The Lees of baudie prewnes: mourning gloves?
All ſpoyl'd by heaven.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Ha! who art thou?

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.l: A ſhame on ye,
Ye clawing ſcabby whore.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I ſay, who art thou?

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Why 'tis the Princeſſe ſir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: The divell ſir,
'Tis ſome rogue thing.

sp.speaker: Who.
sp.l: If this abuſe be love ſir,
Or I that laid aſide my modeſty—

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: So far thou't never find it.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Doe not weepe,
For if ye be the Princeſſe, I will love ye,
Indeed I will, and honour ye, fight for ye,
Come wipe your eyes; by heaven ſhe ſtinkes; who art ta?
Stinkes like a poyſon'd Ratt behind a hanging?
Woman who art ta? like a rotten Cabbage.

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.l: Y'ar much to blame ſir, 'tis the Princeſſe.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: How?
Shee the Princeſſe?

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: And the loving Princeſſe.

sp.speaker: 1. Capt.
sp.l: Indeed the doting Princeſſe.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Come hither once more,
The Princeſſe ſmells like mornings breath, pure Amber,
Beyond the courted Indies in her ſpices
Still a dead rat by heaven; thou art a Princeſſe.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: What a dull whore is this?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I'le tell ye preſently,
For if ſhe be a Princeſſe, as ſhe may be
And yet ſtink too, and ſtrongly, I ſhall find her;
Fetch the Numidian Lyon I brought over,
If ſhe be ſprung from royall blood, the Lyon
He'l doe ye reverence, els

sp.speaker: Who.
sp.l: I beſeech your Lordſhip?

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: He'l teare her all to pieces.

sp.speaker: Who.
sp.l: I am no Princeſſe, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Who brought thee hither?

sp.speaker: 2. Capt.
sp.l: If ye confeſſe, wee'll hang ye.

sp.speaker: Who.
sp.l: Good my Lord;

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Who art thou then?

sp.speaker: Who.
sp.l: A poore retaining whore, ſir,
To one of your Lordſhips Captaines.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Alas poore whore,
Go, be a whore ſtill, and ſtinke worſe: Ha, ha ha Ex. Cloe
What fooles are theſe, and coxcombes? Exit. Memnon.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: I am right glad yet,
He takes it with ſuch lightneſſe.

sp.speaker: 1. Cap.
sp.l: Me thinkes his face too,
Is not ſo clouded as it was; how he lookes?

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Where's your dead Rat?

sp.speaker: 2. Cap.
sp.l: The divell dine upon her
Lyons, why what a medicine had he gotten
To try a whore?

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.p: Here's one from Polidor ſtaies to ſpeak with ye.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: With whom?

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: With all; where has the Generall bin?
Hee's laughing to himſelfe extreamly.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Come,
I'le tell thee how: I am glad yet he's ſo merry. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Prima.
div.stage: Enter Chilax and Prieſt, Calis, Lady and Nun.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: What lights are thoſe that enter there, ſtill neerer?
Plague a your rotten itch, do you draw me hither
Into the Temple to betray me? was there no place
To ſatisfie your ſin in? Gods forgive me,
Still they come forward;

sp.speaker: Prieſt.
sp.l: Peace ye foole, I have found it,
'Tis the young Princeſſe Calis.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: 'Tis the divell
To claw us for our catterwawling.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Retire ſoftly,
I did not looke for you theſe two houres, Lady,
Beſhrew your haſt: that way,

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: That goes to th'Altar?
Ye old blind Beaſt.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I know not any way;
Still they come nearer,
I'le in to th'Oracle;

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: That's well remembred Ile in with ye;

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Doe. Exeunt Prieſt & Chilax.

div.stage: Enter Calis and her Traine with lights ſinging; Lucippe, Cleanthe.

sp.l: O faire ſweet Goddeſſe Queene of Loves,
Soft and gentle, as thy Doves,
Humble ey'd, and ever ruing
Thoſe poore hearts, their Loves purſuing:
O thou mother of delights,
Crowner of all happy nights,
Star of deare content, and pleaſure
Of mutuall loves the endleſſe treaſure,
Accept this ſacrifice we bring
Thou continuall youth and Spring,
Grant this Lady her deſires,
And every houre, wee'll crown thy fires.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.l: You about her all retyre,
Whilſt the Princeſſe feedes the fire,
When your Devotions ended be
To the Oracle I will attend ye. Exit. Nun & draws the Curten cloſe to Calis.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Hee will abroad.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: How does his humour hold him?

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: He is now growne wondrous ſad, weeps often too,
Talkes of his brother to himſelfe, ſtarts ſtrangely.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Does he not curſe?

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Nor breake out in furie,
Offering ſome new attempt?

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: Neither, toth' Temple
Is all we heare of now: what there he will doe;

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: I hope repent his folly, let's be neare him.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Where are the reſt?

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: About a buſineſſe
Concernes him mainly, if heav'n cure this madneſſe,
He's man for ever Stremon.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Does the King know it?

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Yes, and much troubled with it, is now gone
To ſeeke his ſiſter out.
Come let's away then. Exeunt Eumen. Stremon, Caliſ.

div.stage: Enter Nun, ſhe opens the Curtain to Calis. Calis at the Oracle, Arras.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.l: Peace to your praiers Lady, will it pleaſe ye
To paſſe on to the Oracle.

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.p: Moſt humblie. Chilax & Prieſt in the Oracle.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Doe ye heare that?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Yes, lie cloſe.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: A wildfire take ye,
What ſhall become of me? I ſhall be hang'd now.
Is this a time to ſhake? a halter ſhake ye,
Come up and juggle, come.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I am monſtrous fearfull.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Up ye old gaping Oyſter, up and anſwer,
A mouldie mange upon your chops, ye told me
I was ſafe here till the Bell rung.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I was prevented,
And did not looke theſe three houres for the Princeſſe.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Shall we be taken?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Speake for loves ſake Chilax?
I can not, nor I dare not.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.p: I'le ſpeake treaſon, for I had as lieve be hang'd for that

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Good Chilax.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Muſt it be ſung or ſed? what ſhall I tell 'em?
They are here? here now preparing.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: O, my conſcience!

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Plague a your ſpurgall'd conſcience, does it tyre now?
Now when it ſhould be tuffeſt? I could make thee—

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Save us, wee are both undone elſe.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Downe ye dog then,
Be quiet, and be ſtanch to no inundations.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.l: Here kneele againe, and Venus grant your wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: O Divine ſtarre of Heaven,
Thou in power above the ſeven:
Thou ſweet kindler of deſires,
Till they grow to mutuall fires:
Thou, O gentle Queen that art,
Curer of each wounded heart.
Thou the fuell, and the flame;
Thou in heaven, and here the ſame:
Thou the wooer, and the wood:
Thou the hunger, and the food:
Thou the prayer, and the prayed;
Thou what is, or ſhall be ſaid:
Thou ſtill young, and golden treſſed,
Make me by thy Anſwer bleſſed.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: When?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Now ſpeake handſomly, and ſmall by all meanes,
I have told ye what. Thunder.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: But I'le tell you a new tale
Now for my necke verſe; I have heard thy prayers,
And marke me well.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.l: The Goddeſſe is diſpleaſed much,
The Temple ſhakes and totters: ſhe appeares,
Bow, Lady, bow.

sp.speaker: Venus.
sp.l: Purge me the Temple round,
And live by this example henceforth ſound
Virgin, I have ſeene thy teares,
Heard thy wiſhes and thy feares,
Thy holy Incence flew above,
Harke therefore, thy doome in love,
Had thy heart bin ſoft at firſt,
Now thou had'ſt alayd thy thirſt:
Had thy ſtubborne will but bended,
All thy ſorrows here had ended;
Therefore be juſt in love,
And ſtrange fortune thou muſt prove,
And, for thou haſt bin ſterne and coy,
A dead love thou ſhalt enjoy.

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: O gentle goddeſſe!

sp.speaker: Venus.
sp.l: Riſe, thy doome is ſed,
And feare not; I ſhall pleaſe thee with the dead, Ʋenus aſcends.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.l: Goe up into the Temple and there end
Your holy rites, the Goddeſſe ſmiles upon ye.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I'le no more Oracles, nor Miracles,
Nor no more Church worke, Ile be drawn & hang'd firſt:
Am not I torne a pieces with the thunder?
Death, I can ſcarce believe I live yet,
It ga●e me on the buttocks, a cruell, a huge bang,
I had as lieue a had 'em ſcratcht with dog-whips;
Be quiet henceforth, now ye feele the end on't,
I would adviſe ye my old friends the good gentlewoman
Is ſtrucken dumbe and there her grace ſits mumping
Like an old Ape eating a Brawn; ſure the good Goddeſſe
Knew my intent was honeſt, to ſave the Princeſſe.
And how we young men are entic'd to wickedneſſe
By theſe lewd women, I had paid for't els too:
I am monſtrous holy now, and cruel fearefull,
O! 'twas a plaguy thump, charg'd with a vengeance.
sp.stage: Enter Siphax walkes ſoftly over the Stage, and goes in.
sp.l: Woo'd I were well at home; the beſt is 'tis not day:
Who's that? ha? Siphax? I'le be with you anon, ſir,
Ye ſhall be Oracled I warrant ye,
And thunderd too as well as I: your Lordſhip
sp.stage: Enter Memnon, Eumenes, Stremon, and two carrying Torches.
sp.l: Muſt needs enjoy the Princeſſe, yes, ha! torches?
And Memnon comming this way, he's dog mad,
And ten to one appearing thus unto him,
Hee worries me, I muſt goe by him.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Aske me no further queſtions; what art thou?
How doſt thou ſtare? ſtand off; nay looke upon me,
I doe not ſhake, nor feare thee. — Drawes his ſword.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: A will kill me,
This is for Church worke.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Why doſt thou appeare now?
Thou wert fairly ſlain: I know thee Diocles,
And know thine envie to mine honour: but—

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Stay Memnon,
I am a Spirit, and thou canſt not hurt me.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: This is the voyce of Chilax.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: What makes he thus?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: 'Tis true that I was ſlaine in field, but fowly
By multitudes not manhood: therefore marke me,
I doe appeare againe to quit mine honour,
And on thee ſingle.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I accept the challenge.
Where?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: On the Stigian banks

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: When?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Four dayes hence.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Goe noble Ghoſt, I will attend.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I thanke ye.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Ye have ſav'd your throat and handſomly:
Farwell ſir. Exi. Chi.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Sing me the Battell of Peluſium,
In which this Worthie died.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: This will ſpoile all, and make him worſe
Then ere he was, ſitt downe ſir,
And give your ſelfe to reſt.
ARme, arme, arme, arm, the Scouts are all come in
Keepe your rankes cloſe and now your honours win.
Behold from yonder hill, the foe appeares,
Bowes, bills glaves arrowes ſhields, and Speares,
Like a darke wood he comes, or tempest powring,
O view the wings of horſe, the meadows ſcowring,
The vant-guard marches bravely, hark the Drums—dub, dub,
They meet they meet, now the Battell comes,
See how the Arrows fly
That darken all the skie,
Harke how the Trumpets ſound,
Hark how the hills rebound, — Tara-tara-tara.
Hark how the horſes charge: in boyes in boyes in,-tara, tara,
The Battell totters; now the wounds begin,
O how they cry,
O how they dy.
Roome for the valiant Memnon, arm'd with thunder,
See how he breakes the rankes aſunder:
They fly they flie Eumenes has the Chace,
And brave Polibius, makes good his place.
To the plaines to the Woode,
To the Rocks to the floods,
They fly for ſuccour: Follow, follow, follow, Hey, hey.
Harke how the Souldiers hollow
Brave Diocles is dead,
And all his Souldiers fled,
The battell's won, and loſt,
That many a life hath coſt.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Now forward to the Temple. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Are ye gone?
How have I ſcapt this morning? by what miracle?
Sure I am ordain'd for ſome brave end.

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.l: How is it?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Come, 'tis as well as can be.

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.l: But is it poſſible
This ſhould be true you tell me?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: 'Tis moſt certaine.

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.l: Such a groſſe Aſſe to love the Princeſſe?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Peace,
Pull your robe cloſe about ye: you are perfect
In all I taught ye.

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.l: Sure.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Gods give thee good luck,
'Tis ſtrange my braines ſhould ſtill be beating knaverie
For all theſe dangers: but they are needfull miſchiefes,
And ſuch are Nuts to me, and I muſt doe 'em,
You will remember me—

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.l: By this kiſſe Chilax.

sp.speaker: Chilax.
sp.l: No more of that, I feare another Thunder.

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.l: We are not i'th' Temple man.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Peace, here he comes,
Now to our buſineſſe handſomely: away now. Exi. Chilax and Cloe.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: 'Twas ſure the Princeſſe, for he kneel'd unto her,
And ſhe lookt every way: I hope the Oracle
Has made me happy: me I hope ſhe lookt for.
sp.stage: Enter Chilax and Cloe at the other doore.
sp.l: Fortune, I will ſo honour thee, Love ſo adore thee,
She is here againe lookes round about againe too,
'Tis done, I know 'tis done; 'tis Chilax with her,
And I ſhall know of him; whoſe that?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Speake ſoftly,
The Princeſſe from the Oracle.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: She views me,
By heav'n ſhe beckens me.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Come neare, ſhe woo'd have ye.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: O royall Lady. Kiſſes her hand.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: She wills ye read that, for belike ſhe's bound to ſi|lence
For ſuch a time; ſhe is wondrous gracious to ye.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Heav'n make me thankfull.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: She woo'd have ye read it, He Reads.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Siphax, the will of Heaven hath caſt me on thee
To be thy wife, whoſe will muſt be obay'd:
Uſe me with honour, I ſhall love thee dearly,
And make thee underſtand thy worths hereafter;
Convey me to a ſecret Ceremony,
That both our hearts and loves may be united,
And uſe no language, till before my brother
We both appeare, where I will ſhew the Oracle,
For till that time I am bound, I muſt not anſwer.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: O happy I!

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Ye are a made man.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: But Chilax
Where are her women?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: None but your Graces Siſter,
Becauſe ſhe would have it privat to the world yet,
Knowes of this buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: I ſhall thanke the Chilax,
Thou art a carefull man.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Your Graces ſervant.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: I'le find a ſit place for thee.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: If you will not,
There's a good Lady will, ſhe points yee forward,
Away and take your fortune, not a word ſir,
So, you are greas'd I hope. Exit Siph. & Cloe. manet Chi.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Where have you left your Lord?

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: I'th' Temple, Chilax.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Why are ye from him?

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Why the King is with him,
And all the Lords.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Is not the Princeſſe there too.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Yes,
And the ſtrangeſt coile amongſt 'em: She weeps bitterly;
The King entreats, and frownes, my Lord like Autumne
Drops off his hopes by handfulls, all the Temple
Sweats with this Agonie.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Where's young Polidor?

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Dead as they ſaid o'th' ſudden.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Dead?

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: For certaine,
But not yet knowne abroad,

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: There's a new trouble;
A brave young man he was; but we muſt all die.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Did not the Generall meet you this morning
Like a tall ſtallion Nun?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: No more a that Boy.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: You had been ferreting.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: That's all one, Foole;
My Maſter foole that taught my wits to traffique,
What has your wiſdome done? how have you profited?
Out with your Audit, come: you are not emptie,
Put out mine eye with twelve pence? do you ſhaker?
What thinke you of this ſhaking? here's with coxcombe
Ha boyes? ha my fine raſcalls, here's a Ring, Pulls out a Purſe.
How right they goe?

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: O let me ring the fore-bell.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: And here are thumpers, Chickens, golden rogues,
●it wit ye raſcalls.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: I have a Sty here Chilax.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I have no gold to cure it, not a penny,
Not one croſſe Cavalier; we are dull Sou'diers,
Groſſe, heavy-headed fellowes; fight for victualls?

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Why; ye are the ſpirits of the time.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: By no meanes.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: The valiant firie.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Fy, fie no.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Be-lee-me ſir.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I woo'd I could ſir.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.l: I will ſatisfie ye.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: But I will not content you; alas poore boy,
Thou ſhewſt an honeſt nature weepes for thy Maſter,
There's a red rogue to buy thee handkerchers.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: A was an honeſt Gentleman, I have loſt too.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Ye have indeed your labour Foole; but Stremon,
Doeſt thou want money too? no virtue living?
No firking out at fingers ends?

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: It ſeemes ſo.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Will ye all ſerve me?

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Yes, when ye are Lord Generall,
For leſſe I will not goe.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: There's gold for thee then,
Thou haſt a ſouldiers minde, Foole.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.l: Here, your firſt man.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I will give thee for thy wit, for 'tis a fine wit,
A daintie diving wit, hold up; juſt nothing,
Goe graze i'th' commons, yet I am mercifull
There's ſix pence; buy a Saucer, ſteale an old gowne,
And beg i'th' Temple for a Prophet, come away boyes,
Let's ſee how things are carried, Foole, up ſirra,
You may chance get a dinner: Boy your preferment
I'le undertake, for your brave Maſters ſake,
You ſhall not periſh.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Pleaſe me well Foole,
And you ſhall light my pipes: Away to th' Temple.
But ſtay, the Kings here, ſport upon ſport Boyes.

div.stage: Enter King, Lords Siphax kneeling, Cloe with a Vaile.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What would you have Captaine,
Speake ſuddenly, for I am wondrous buſie.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: A Pardon, Royall ſir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: For what?

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: For that,
Which was heav'ns will, ſhould not be mine alone ſir;
My marrying with this Lady.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It needs no Pardon,
For marriage is no ſin.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Not in it ſelfe, ſir,
But in preſuming too much: Yet heav'n knowes
So does the Oracle that caſt it on me,
And — the Princeſſe, royall ſir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What Princeſſe?

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: O be not angrie, my dread King, your Siſter.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My ſiſter? ſhe's i'th' Temple man.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: She is here ſir.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: The Captain's mad, ſhe is kneeling at the Altar.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I know ſhe is, with all my heart good Captain,
I do forgive ye both: be unvail'd Lady; Puts off her vaile
Will ye have more forgivenes? the mans frantick,
Come let's goe bring her out: God give yee joy ſir.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.p: How? Cloe? my old Cloe? Exit. King, Lords.

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.l: Even the ſame ſir.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Gods give your manhood much c●ntent.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: The Princeſſe
Lookes ſomething muſtie ſince her comming over.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.l: 'Twere good, youl'd bruſh her over.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: Fooles and Fidlers
Make ſport at my abuſe too.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: O 'tis the nature
Of us Fooles to make bold with one another,
But you are wiſe, brave ſirs.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Cheere up your Princeſſe,
Believe it ſir, the King will not be angry,
Or ſay he were; why 'twas the Oracle,
The Oracle, and like your Grace, the Oracle.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: And who, moſt mighty Siphax?

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: With mine owne whore.

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.l: With whom els ſhould ye marry ſpeak your conſcience,
Will ye tranſgreſſe the law of Armes, that ever
Rewards the Souldier with his owne ſins?

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: Devills.

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.l: Ye had my maiden-head my youth, my ſweetnes,
Is it not juſtice then? —

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: I ſee it muſt be,
But by this hand. I'le hang a lock upon thee.

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.l: You ſhall not need, my honeſty ſhall doe it.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: If there be wars in all the world—

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.l: I'le with ye,
For you know, I have bin a ſouldier,
Come, curſe on: when I need another Oracle.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Send for me Siphax, I'le fit ye with a Princeſſe,
And ſo to both your honours.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: And your graces.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: The Devill grace ye all.

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.l: God a mercy Chilax,

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Shall we laugh halfe an houre now?

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: No the King comes,
And all the traine.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Away then, our Act's ended. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter King, Caliſ. Memnon and Cleanthe, Curtiſan, Lords.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You know he do's deſerve ye, loves ye dearly,
You know what bloody violence had us'd The Hearſe ready Poli|dor, Eu|menes & Captains
Upon himſelfe, but that his brother croſt it,
You know the ſame thoughts ſtill inhabit in him
And covet to take birth: Look on him Lady,
The wars have not ſo far conſum'd him yet,
Cold age diſabled him, or ſickneſſe ſunk him
To be abhorr'd: looke on his Honour ſiſter,
That beares no ſtamp of time, no wrinkles on it,
No ſad demoliſhment, nor death can reach it:
Looke with the eyes of heaven that nightlie waken,
To view the wonders of my glorious Maker,
And not the weakneſſe: looke with your vertuous eyes,
And then clad royaltie in all his conqueſts;
His matchleſſe love hung with a thouſand merits
Eternall youth attending, Fame and Fortune,
Time and Oblivion vexing at his vertues,
He ſhall appeare a miracle: looke on our dangers,
Looke on the publique ruine.

sp.speaker: Caliſ.
sp.l: O, deare brother.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Fie, let us not like proud and greedy waters
Gaine, to give off againe: this is our Sea,
And you his Cynthia, govern him, take heed,
His ſtouds have bin as hie, and full as any,
And gloriouſly now is got up to the girdle,
The Kingdomes he hath purchas'd; noble Siſter,
Take not your vertue from him, O take heed
We ebbe not now to nothing, take heed Calis.

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: The wil of heaven not mine, which muſt not alter,
And my eternall doome for ought I know
Is fixt upon me; alas, I muſt love nothing.
Nothing that loves againe muſt I be bleſt with:
The gentle Vine climbs up the Oke and clips him.
And when the ſtroke comes, yet they fall together;
Death death muſt I enjoy, and live to love him,
O noble Sir!

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Thoſe teares are ſome reward yet,
Pray let me wed your ſorrowes.

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: Take 'em Souldier,
They are fruitfull ones, lay but a fight upon 'em,
And ſtrait they will conceive to infinites;
I told ye what, ye could find 'em,
Roome before there. Knock.

div.stage: Enter Funerall, Captaines following, and Eumenes.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How now, what's this? more drops to th'Ocean?
Whoſe body's this?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: The noble Polidor,
This ſpeakes his death.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: My Brother dead?

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: O Goddeſſe!
O cruell, cruell Venus, here's my fortune.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Read Captaine.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Read aloude: farewell my follies. Eumen reades

sp.speaker: 1. Cap.
sp.l: Be wiſe, as you are beauteous, love with judgement,
And look with clear eyes on my noble Brother,
Value deſert and vertue, they are Jewells,
Fit for your worth and wearing: take heed Lady,
The Gods reward ingratitude moſt grievous;
Remember me no more, or if you muſt,
Seeke me in noble Memnons love, I dwell there:
I durſt not live, becauſe I durſt not wrong him,
I can no more, make mee eternall happy
With looking downe upon your loves.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: And did'ſt thou die for me?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Excellent vertue!
What will ye now doe?

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: Dwell for euer here ſir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: For me deare Polidor? ô worthy young man!
O love, love, love, love above recompence!
Infinite love, infinite honeſty!
Good Lady leave, you muſt have no ſhare here,
Take home your ſorrowes: here's enough to ſtore me,
Brave glorious griefes! was ever ſuch a brother?
Turne all the ſtories over in the world yet,
And ſearch through all the memories of mankind,
And find me ſuch a friend; h'as out-done all.
Outſtript 'em ſheerely, all, all, thou haſt Polidor,
To die for me; why, as I hope for happineſſe,
'Twas one of the rareſt thought on things
The braveſt, and carried beyond compaſſe of our actions,
I wonder how he hit it, a young man too,
In all the bloſſomes of his youth and beautie,
In all the fulneſſe of his veines and wiſhes
Woed by that Paradice, that would catch heaven;
It ſtarts me extreamly, thou bleſt Aſhes,
Thou faithfull monument, where loue and friendſhip
Shall while the world is, worke new miracles.

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: O! let me ſpeake too.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: No not yet, thou man,
For we are but mans ſhadowes, only man,
I have not words to utter him; ſpeake Lady,
I'le thinke a while.

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: The Goddeſſe grants me this yet,
I ſhall enjoy the dead: no tombe ſhall hold thee
But theſe two armes, no Trickments but my teares
Over thy Hearſe, my ſorrowes like ſad armes
Shall hang for ever: on the tuffeſt Marble
Mine eyes ſhall weepe thee out an Epitaph,
Love at thy feet ſhall kneele, his ſmart bow broken;
Faith at thy head, youth and the Graces mourners;
O ſweet young man!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now I begin to melt too.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Have ye enough yet Lady? roome for a gamſter
To my fond Love, and all thoſe idle fancies
A long farwell, thou diedſt for me deare Polidor,
To give me peace, thou haſt eternall glory,
I ſtay and talke here; I will kiſſe thee firſt,
And now I'le follow thee. Polidor riſes.

sp.speaker: Pollidor.
sp.l: Hold, for heavens ſake!

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Ha!
Does he live?
Doſt thou deceive me?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Thus farre,
Yet for your good, and honour.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now deare ſiſter;

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: The Oracle is ended, noble ſir,
Diſpoſe, me now as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: You are mine then?

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: With all the joyes that may be.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Your conſent ſir;

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ye have it freely.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Walke along with me then,
And as you love me, love my will.

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: I will ſo.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Here worthy Brother, take this vertuous Princeſſe,
Ye have deſerv'd her nobly, ſhe will love ye,
And when my life ſhall bring ye peace, as ſhe does,
Command it, ye ſhall have it.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Sir, I thanke ye.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I never found ſuch goodneſſe in ſuch yeares.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt not over-doe me, though I die for't,
O how I love thy goodneſſe, my beſt brother,
You have given me here a treaſure to enrich me,
Would make the worthieſt King alive a begger,
What may I give you back againe?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Your love ſir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: And you ſhall have it, even my deareſt love,
My firſt, my nobleſt love, take her againe, ſir,
She is yours, your honeſty has over-run me,
She loves ye, lov'ſt her not? excellent Princeſſe,
Injoy thy wiſh, and now get Generalls.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: As ye love heaven, love him, ſhe is only yours, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: As ye love heaven, love him, ſhe is only yours, ſir;
My Lord, the King.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: He will undoe himſelfe ſir,
And muſt without her periſh; who ſhall fight then?
Who ſhall protect your Kingdome?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Give me hearing,
And after that beliefe, were ſhe my ſoule
(As I doe love her equall) all my victories,
And all the living names I have gain'd by warre,
And loving him that good, that vertuous good man,
That only worthy of the name of brother,
I would reſigne all freely, 'tis all love
To me, all marriage rites, the joy of iſſues
To know him fruitfull, that has been ſo faithfull.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: This is the nobleſt difference-take your choiſe ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: I ſee they are ſo brave, and noble both,
I know not which to looke on.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Chuſe diſcreetly,
And vertue guide ye, there all the world in one man
Stands at the marke.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: There all mans honeſtie,
The ſweetneſſe of all youth —

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: O God's!

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: My Armour,
By all the God's ſhe's yours; my armes, I ſay,
And I beſeech your Grace, give me imployment,
That ſhall be now my Miſtreſſe: here my Courtſhip.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ye ſhall have any thing.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Vertuous Lady,
Remember me, your ſervant now; Young man,
You cannot over-reach me in your goodneſſe;
O love! how ſweet thou look'ſt now? and how gentle,
I ſhould have ſlubber'd thee, and ſtain'd thy beauty;
Your hand, your hand ſir;

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Take her, and Heaven bleſſe her.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: 'Tis your will ſir, nothing of my merit;
And as your royall gift, I take this bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: And I from heaven this gentleman: thanks Goddeſs.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: So ye are pleas'd now Lady;

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Now or never.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: My cold ſtiffe carkaſſe, would have frozen ye,
Warres, warres.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ye ſhall have warres.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: My next brave battell
I dedicate to your bright honour (ſiſter,)
Give me a favour, that the world may know
I am your ſouldier.

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: This, and all faire Fortunes.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: And he that beares this from me, muſt ſtrike boldly.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I do forgive thee: be honeſt, no more wench.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Come now to Revells, this bleſt day ſhall prove
The happy crown of noble Faith and Love. Exeunt.

div.head: Prologue.
div.l: TO pleaſe all's impoſſible, and to deſpaire
Ruins our ſelves, and dampes the Writers care:
Would we knew what to doe, or ſay, or when
To find the mindes here equall with the men:
But we muſt venture; now to Sea we goe,
Faire fortune with us, give us roome, and blow;
Remember ye'ar all venturers; and in this Play
How many twelve-pences ye have 'ſtow'd this day:
Remember for returne of your delight,
We launch, and plough through ſtormes of feare, and ſpight:
Give us your fore-windes fairely, fill our wings,
And ſteere us right, and as the Saylors ſing,
Loden with Wealth, on wanton ſeas, ſo we
Shall make our home-bound-voyage chearfully;
And you our noble Merchants, for your treaſure
Share equally the fraught, we run for pleaſure.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: HEre lyes the doubt now, let our Playes be good,
Our owne care ſayling equall in this Flood;
Our preparations new, new our Attire,
Yet here we are becalm'd ſtill, ſtill i'th' mire,
Here we ſtick faſt; Is there no way to cleare
This paſſage of your judgement, and our feare,
No mittigation of that law? Brave friends,
Conſider we are yours, made for your ends,
And every thing preſerves it ſelfe, each will
If not perverſe, and crooked, utters ſtill
The beſt of that it ventures in: have care
Ev'n for your pleaſures ſake, of what we are,
And doe not ruine all: You may frowne ſtill.
But 'tis the nobler way, to check the will.
